Anyway, if you are a big fish (or maybe a mini-whale), I'm sure you won't care, but for us mortals, it sort of matters that this really is a pretty bad deal.  And Wynn's comps sort of suck... grrr... sorry, off topic again.

Extremely overpriced, average-quality Chinese food. Service was also pretty bad...after being seated, we waited almost 30 min before our waiter came by, who proceeded to recommend the three most expensive things on the menu. He kept trying to up-sell us through the whole dinner which nearly ruined the experience. The one saving grace of this place is the great atmosphere and cool decor. I would hesitantly recommend this place if you don't mind average food and a pushy, inattentive wait staff.

Not so cheap, not so expensive.
Loved baked beans and fried rice. 
Hope they don't have "Shaoxingjiu" (Chinese alcohol made from rice). Its good with Chinese foods so want them serve it soon.

6????????6500?????
????????????????????XO?????????????????????
??????????????????
???????1??????????????????
?????????????

I want a refund! This is a huge disappointment as a restraunt in the Wynn Hotel.The service was terrible, the food was sub-standard. How does a chef destroy a simple green bean sauté dish? It was excessively salty and the garlic flavor was highly suspicious.
The "egg noodles" we're more likely ramen noodles and the soup was bland and boring. I've had better at the Panda Express in the mall.

Save your money. Save your time. They need an overhaul here And sooner rather than later. Mr Wynn has obviously not eaten here or this wouldn't have been our experience.

Real rating- 3.5, extra half star for really great service!

Red 8 provides a nice ambience without crazy Vegas hotel dining prices. Don't get me wrong, it is by no means cheap but it isn't very expensive either. 

The food is not extraordinary but good enough, even though one of the dishes was really salty. 

Overall, there aren't many decently priced, nice places for Chinese food on the strip so Red 8 is a good option if Chinese is what you're looking for.

It is Sunday in Vegas.  What a wild two nights it was.  We needed something to help clear away the cobwebs of overindulgence.  Upon arriving at the Wynn hotel we were greeted by the nicest doorman.  We walked inside and headed to Red 8. 

Great food with perfect spice.  For an appetizer I had the Pork Wonton.  This is not fried but steamed.  Great flavor and excellent burn.  For an entree I had the Pork Eggplant with the hand formed "pigs ear" noodles.  I could not stop eating.  A large portion that was excellent.

Thank you.

Fast Chinese restaurant that serves standard Asian food. I like how this place also has specialty teas. I get the lychee green tea. 

Food: their hot and sour soup is very good

Main entree: I get the Mapo tofu here. Sometimes they have lunch specials where I got a braised pork belly. They change often so check back. This place gets very crowded.

2.5 stars
First time i ate here 2-3 years ago, I really loved it.
Ordered identical items this trip; the combo fried rice, and pad-thai.
Didnt like them at all; in fact pick-up-dixx makes a better both, at an 80% discount.
$85 bucks for one tsingtao (damn love that chinese beer), diet coke, 2 entrees mentioned, and a spring roll appetizzy (decent)
Ridiculous prices, even for the Wynn. And mind you, probably ate the lowest priced entrees on the menu, or darn near the bottom. Not from cheapness, I like those items (well, LIKED.)
Waited 40 minutes when told about a 20-25 minute wait.
They dont take reservations and are a bit disorganized in that dept.
Service was attentive, just disappointed quality of items has gone downhill (add to the list in this city)
If you love panda express then this place will flip your untasty noodle.

Red 8 is an amazing authentic Chinese restaurant with great ambiance. My husband and I stay at the Wynn 2-3 times per year and always have a meal at Red 8 when we are in town. Great service, extensive menu, late hours...I would recommend you check it out!

This is a nice place to eat. The service was very good and getting seated was quick. the prices were very good for a sit down restaurant in the Wynn.  

I had the Kung Pao Chicken and it was OK. The flavor was pretty bland for a spicy dish and it had nothing special about it. My wife enjoyed the cashew chicken.  So I my review would be that if I needed to get dinner and could not walk elsewhere then I would go here.

The restaurant near XS was closed so my wife and I decided to come here. We really enjoyed the vegan options they had. The price was about a hundred dollars for the both of us. We only had the dim sum and one order of lettuce wrap. The Gardein Shumai was pretty good for not being the real thing, but the dumplings stuck together. The Gardein Buns were really good. Overall we really enjoyed ourselves. Great atmosphere and friendly service, even though it was pretty slow. The food was pretty good too. I believe I wouldn't have enjoyed it as much if I wasn't a vegan.
Penang style flat noodles are great. Not spicy enough but very good. Lots of big shrimp in my dish so that was very nice.  Not a cheap place but quality is great.

I agree with the other reviews that Red 8 is very expensive for what it is.  I'm picky when it comes to Chinese food, and Red 8 does not cut it.  I've been there twice.  The first time I had a very bland braised beef noodle soup.  The second time I tried the lunch special for $18.88 (so azn).  The special came with kung pao chicken, a potsticker, and a spring roll.  The kung pao chicken tasted like lean cuisine-- painfully bland.  The spring roll looked like something I might throw in the microwave at home.  Finally, the potsticker was good-- but my meal only came with one, so big whoop.  I've also sampled the dim sum, which is good, but pricey as hell-- even for Vegas.  I think we've learned our lesson and won't be back.

I found Red 8 to be a fantastic experience from greeting to paying the bill. The food was absolutely fantastic. Especially enjoyed the wasabi shrimp. 
The service was warm and efficient.  And it isn't crazy priced. I would suggest that anyone looking to enjoy multiple fantastic choices of Asian style cuisine must eat at Red 8. And don't bother with a reservation, they don't take them. Just go in and they seat you. Great job chef and staff of Red 8. 
We will be back again and again.

Two stars + "Meh. I've experienced better," and that's exactly how I felt about this place. I ordered Dan Dan Noodles, which should be a spicy Sechuan dish. There was even a chili pepper next to it to mark it as spicy. I *adore* a nice bowl of Dan Dan noodles, so I was looking forward to this. When I ordered it, the waiter asked, "have you had this before? " because he wanted to be sure I knew it was spicy. I assured him I've had it many times. Total let down.  A teaspoon of chili paste sitting on top of the noodles was the *only* bit of spicy. No chili oil? Not even the mince pork had any heat. The broth was basically dish water. Zero depth of flavor.  I asked the waiter for more chili paste. I think he sensed my disappointment because he gave me like three tablespoons' worth. I used probably half of it to get any semblance of heat. So yeah, if you like really Americanized Chinese, maybe this place will work for you.

Popped in for a very late dinner here while staying at the Encore. The food was great-prawn din sum were perfectly prepared and flavorful, veggie curry was flavorful with yummy tofu and veggies and  my wife's panang noodles were outstanding. Prices were reasonable and portions were not skimpy. 

The place loses two stars, however, for service. Our waiter never came back to check on drink refills until we were long done and it took ages to get the check. There was hardly anyone there at the late hour so there really was no excuse. It's too bad because it would have been five stars otherwise.

The best vegan dim sum 
Vegan food done right
Nice atmosphere and great service a yummy choice for vegans in Vegas

Beautiful dining room, friendly and attentive staff but overpriced for the food. I don't mind paying high prices, but for high quality food. Honestly I have had better chinese food for a fraction of the price. But I guess you're paying for the beautiful tables and linens so it's not fair to compare them to a hole in the wall Chinese place in the Bay Area. But then again, it's also not fair to serve mediocre food at very high prices. I think my 1 serving bowl of hot and sour soup was something like $14. But, the coffee is always fresh and delicious and they give you a crystallized sugar stick, cool! Still, we always order way too much food and still enjoy ourselves. After all this is Vegas, you come to splurge and let loose. So 4 stars for me! =)

Uhhhh! I knew why it is cheaper than other restaurants, cauz they got a rude cashier waitress. I ordered a pick up and wait 1 hour( which she said 30minutes). When I ask if my order is ready, she shouted at me?! 
And the reason she yelled at me is "I'm too busy". Then I ask her to apologize, she did but then ask her manager to tell me she's pregnant(well I don't know if it's true since I'm not an X-ray)
 I know a pregnant is innocent and tough, but can u yell at others who you not even know as a "pregnant "? I wondering will you tell your customers u r still a pregnant after u yell at them in 1 year.

Really nice vegan dishes! I mean...aside from everything in the vegetarian section of the menu being either a) already vegan or b) capable of altered to be vegan, they even had vegan dim sum!!! Dim sum is the thing I missed the most since going vegan tbh. This places is amazing. It's quite pricey, but I'd rather throw my money down here and eat a bunch of vegan dim sum to satisfy my cravings, rather than a giant Vegas buffet where I can eat like 4 things. They use a lot of gardein "meats" as dumpling filler and also for their "chicken" wraps. Really delicious!

The best part is, this restaurant has awesome noodles soups too, so my meat-eating family can enjoy a meal with me in the same place! My dad, who is just about the most judgmental eater in the world, genuinely liked their beef brisket soup with egg noodles. He raved about how satisfied he was and then got the fresh mango sago for dessert (which he also gobbled up in record time). Mom loved the wonton soup with egg noodles, and my husband got the stir fried noodles with beef, which he cleaned the plate of.

The only thing that was weak was the black sesame porridge. Definitely not sweet enough, which is a shame because it's one of my favorites! Service is meh, but we came for the food and we left quite satisfied!

This is my favorite lunch place in all of Vegas (I havet o admit that I absolutely adore Asian food) and it's located in my favorite hotel in Vegas, too. I'd recommend everyone give it a try - I don't think you'll be upset.

SERVICE: My service hasn't been anything terrible or stellar in previous visits. My most recent visit had GREAT service - a nice Southern girl who took several pictures of our table, gave us drink and food recommendations and didn't rush us at all. The hostess agreed to let us have this great "bird cage" table/room even though there were only five of us - so nice!

FOOD: This place is like an upscale P.F. Chang's with a larger menu. Our table ordered the panang noodles, the pad thai (with chicken instead of shrimp) and the Kung Pao chicken. Everyone at themselves silly because although the portions are HUGE, the food was so good and no one wanted to leave a noodle behind.

DRINKS: Two of our diners had a mojito and LOVED them - they even had bamboo sticks in them. Really cute. I turned the mocktail lemonade into a cocktail with gin and liked that pretty well, too. Great drink menu for a lunch stop.

ATMOSPHERE: I like the color scheme in this restaurant and have never been disappointed with the table we've been given. One thing I would admit: the other diners in my group did not find the chairs very comfortable.

OVERALL: This is seriously my favorite lunch place in Vegas - a must-stop while we're there. Don't worry about meals long after - you'll be full for the next five hours.

The food was just okay...  there was nothing spectacular about it.  Our table ordered pot stickers, hot and sour soup, beef with bitter melon, assorted BBQ, and chicken chow mein.

It reminded me of PF Changs (which I don't really like).  The decor was odd... for the most part it was very sleek and modern... then they had wicker chairs.   I thought it would be more expensive since it was in the Wynn... but it was still pricey for what it was.  For example  the $9 hot and sour soup ended up being an appetizer for one.  (We thought it was going to be family style).
Dinner here late Friday evening. We had several dim sum plates and they were good. The roasted duck was good. The boba tea was average. Service was good.

Service was nice, but the food.....my second time here after 3years.....don't recall the first time if I liked it?  but my husband wanted Chinese.....really sorry to say that we felt even Panda Express was better than here =(
decent but not extraordinary Hong Kong noodle house cuisine, but WAY overpriced ($7 for a pot of hot tea? An outrage!) Staff was attentive and professional.

this place is a very up scale chinese restaurant that i wont be coming to again lol. we only came here because another place wouldnt let us go in with our shorts on so lame.

the 7 of us ate family style, we did the assorted bbq, the duck, the mongolian beef, the fried rice, something noodle, kung pao chicken.

im chinese so i know what its suppose to taste like haha and it wasnt as good as home but it was kinda tasty? but do you want to pay 150% more than like panda express for kinda tasty food?

the service there is like any other asian place, nonexistent. ill admit since this place is in the Wynn its super nice, but its very sub par to me. for what im paying at least, i shouldnt have to ask for refills, please check on my table.

and what is with the being cheap on rice at asian places? rice is super cheap and it cost nothing to make a shit ton, and yet the 7 of us had to share 3 small bowls. so lame.

I wish we checked the Yelp rating and reviews before coming here. That was for sure the worst Asian food I've had and definitely the most unhealthy. We ordered the special - rice noodles with duck. There was no duck meet just duck skin, so disgusting. The fried rice with shrimp and steak had no taste and again the meat was hard to find. We had to pour a good amount of soy sauce to make it edible. The very high price bottle of wine we ordered wasn't good either. I can only imagine it was a overpriced cheap wine. Never going back there again. Unhealthy, bland, overpriced food.

We got to Vegas at 10 am and went straight to our hotel Encore to check in. we got hungry so we walked over to Wynn and found Red 8. me n my friend ordered 1 lunch plate together that had potsticker, eggroll, orange chicken n rice. then we ordered pork and shrimp dumpling...n we were still hungry! so we ordered a plate of bbq pork with rice on the side and of course we had mango pudding for dessert! after all that we were satisfied =) the service was great...refilled our water without us asking for it...they were attentive and overall a great restaurant! ohh n it was time for a nap after all that food....

The oxtail soup is out of the world, very reasonable pricing 
Staff are very friendly and welling to go out of there way to make you happy 
Dumpling are also amazing 
I will be back before end of my visit

I've been here several times, and I try to stick with the Dim Sum, as I've learned that it's the least mediocre food that they seem to offer.  They try to be authentic with their menu, which, it sure looks like it, but I think they've toned down some of the flavors for... I don't know... There's a shit ton of Asians that go through the Wynn, why they wouldn't try catering to that palette is beyond me. They must have white people as Chefs.

The service is iffy, and there's usually a wait to get in.

The restaurant interior is really pretty, though... I like Red, and wood, apparently.

My friend and I were walking around the Wynn hotel and other local hotels nearby to see if anything interest us like at midnight. We previewed their menu and the first thing that made us say "yes" to it was the roasted duck.

Our hostess was very kind to seat us away from the smokers & everybody else, plus it was at a booth :)

Our server was on top of things, he filled our drinks when it was half-full, generously offered to refill our soy sauce, and checked on us a lot to see if we're doing fine.

We ordered the roasted duck, which was small, but for a good amount, it was really delicious. Cooked to perfection, no burnt tasting flavors, and the sauce that came with it was absolutely magnificent to our taste buds. We also ordered some Curry-rice noodles with pork and veggies (signature dish). Hint of spicy, but it was awesome pair with our steamed vegetables.

Great food, service, and decent price. I would want to go here again, and possibly try other signature dishes too. The place has a very Asian theme to it. Nicely decorated & some fine Ming porcelains.

Something you don't see too often... a high end Chinese restaurant that is still moderately priced. They label it a casual Asian bistro and that's exactly what it is, albeit the fact that it's right in the heart of the Wynn Hotel, which is anything but.

Being so close to the casino floor, the type of energy and noise spills into the restaurant, which works in this case. The food also is nothing too foreign that you need a server to help you understand  it, but fast food takeout superstars like fried rice, mapu tofu and chicken satay are all on the menu here and done with an obvious higher attention to detail. Only bad thing was the service was noticeabley a bit scattered.

Dimsum at the Wynn? Yes. Is it legit? Yes. Will i return. Yes. Wasnt it expensive? Who cares

*must order Shumai.
The food was done well, service was professional and friendly.  For an Asian experience in Vegas it's worth the trip to the Wynn.  Try the dumplings, walnut shrimp and beef noodle soup!

$3 for a bowl of rice!!! Yikes! Late night dining options at the Wynn were limited and led us to this place. We ordered bbq pork, bbq duck and two bowls of rice $45. OMG! Sam Woo bbq we could of eaten the same thing for like $15 and it would of tasted better. I don't mind paying for a good meal, but being over charged for mediocre food just makes me pout. The server was an automaton, no smile, no energy, no emotion. Sad, Wynn, Sad! I just wanted a tasty late night dinner but no go at Red 8.

Hong kong crispy noodle with seafood is good. Descent portion. Not a lot of flavor but that was ok with me. It was $24. Chilean seabass $35 was a really good portion surprisingly. It was very good. Sever told us anything with seafood don't expect a lot of seafood in the dish. I have seen other reviewers say the same

My friends and I came to Red 8 for one of our dinners in Vegas.  Since it was located in our hotel, it was quite convenient.  I thought it was interesting as they offer menu items from China, Thailand, India, Vietnam, Singapore, and Korea such as Cantonese noodle dishes, dim sum, duck, Mongolian Beef, and Hong Kong style barbecue.  We started off with the Malaysian Chicken Satay that came with a side of chunky peanut sauce - the chicken was okay, and the the chunky peanut sauce was more on the sweeter side.  I had the Penang-Style Rice Flat Noodles with Chicken and I wasn't a fan of the dish as it lacked flavor.  I did like the flat noodles, though, but they were overcooked.  One of my friends had the Curried Singapore Rice Vermicelli that contained shredded pork, shrimp, egg, and bean sprouts - she enjoyed it, but I wasn't a fan of the different spices that were used.  The restaurant itself had a nice decor with the combination of red and black colors.  Definitely on the pricier side as it is located in the hotel!

+located inside the Wynn

This is by far one of thee best places to grub!!!
Amazing atmosphere, delicious food and great service
This place is amazing! We always make a point to stop here when we are in town. They have wonderful vegan options and everything is so tasty. Wait staff are very friendly.

One of my favorite places to eat in Las Vegas. Have been coming to Red 8 for years, and love its fancy Asian diner vibe. Great for late night noodles and peoplewatching. Trytge congee if you are adventurous... The standard dim sun fixings are great, love the wide Penang style wok- fried noodles. Service can be a bit slow, but the food is worth it. A bargain in the Wynn hotel.

So the food here was pretty good - we ordered lamb, chili chicken, beef, veg, honey walnut shrimp, cashew chicken ...all ordered steamed rice but of course two of us got no rice despite walking out of the dining area to ask for it from the servers!  Understandably it can be family style but when a table asks for individual sides of rice perhaps you should do them the courtesy of delivering it!  I like to eat well and usually that guest service is rewarded however this is a place I won't go back to!

Chinese place in the Wynn hotel. Very pricey but hey it's Vegas. Service was very good and the food was better than average. 

Had the hot and sour soup and sweet and sour chicken. All was good, solid place if price isn't an issue and you don't want to leave the hotel.
Ok.  This place isn't exactly open to 12.  Just went by and they actually stop serving at 11.30.  Not sure why they don't just say that.  Travelled quite a ways to be here so a bit disappointed.

I don't know why it has good rating. This restaurant looks beautiful and very Chinese, but I didn't get good service. I wanted to get some water but I didn't get it until 30 minutes I finished my dinner. No one asked me if we were ok. Also, the food was not very good. We ordered steamed fish, beans, beef and dessert, and the only thing acceptable for me was the fish. I don't like the beef. It was not juicy enough and it was quite dry and old.

Didn't know where to eat and I'm not a big fan of Chinese food.  Ended up at the Wynn. Walked around to check out menus at all the restaurants at the Wynn and decided to give it a try.  Love everything we ordered.  The potstickers were the best I've ever had. Now craving them in fact. We also had chicken lettuce wraps, BBQ pork belly, dim sum,  lobster ragoon and chicken fried rice. The rice looked a little funky and cheap, but it was great.  Everything was very fresh. Our waiter said everything was made to order on the premises. Price was reasonable for the Wynn.  I would highly recommend this place.

Mediocre chinese food in the Wynn.  One of the lesser expensive restaurants in the hotel (among many very expensive restaurants).  Would have preferred to have gone to a nice restaurant at the hotel but this is one of the few that allows kids under 5.
Used to be good. But not anymore. Took 1hr to have two dimsum plates even after lunch time.  Salty shumai, not fresh...no worth paying $9 for that.

Dim sum was pretty good.  Get the shrimp/mushroom selection.  Dim sum extended menu not available every day, I believe only Mon-Fri.  It's chinese food, so slightly oily, but I did love the chinese broccoli.  Espresso was very good and I like the presentation (comes with candied sugar on a stick).  A decent lunch choice.

Our family went to Red 8 inside of Wynn Las Vegas for lunch.  Food was wonderful!  Service was impeccable, quick and attentive.  Even the manager came to ask us about the food and service.  We went back for dinner next day.  Delicious food and great service!

red 8, ive been my first time about 2 years ago with a group of family and the food was excellent a bit pricey but very good but thats vegas for ya, the beef was mouth melting and most fusion places and chinese places the beef is chewy but not this one i enjoyed every piece and so did my family, they usually have a long wait so get there early an put your name down if you are in vegas you must try!

Take it from an actual Chinese person.
Honestly... not bad!

I cringed as we entered this over-the-top fancy Asian fusion restaurant inside the Wynn. On the menu I saw Japanese edamame but also Chinese dumplings. Oh boy. Here we go.

Cracked open the menu and cringed even more at the prices... Chinese food is supposed to be cheap. What the hell is this $20 chow mein and $9 for 3 dumplings? Whatever, we were crunched on time and needed to eat at the hotel before going out. Also we are at The Wynn. Oh yeah also we are in VEGAS ANYWAYS MOVING ON-

Service was extremely slow (or maybe because we were in a hurry) but after you order, the food comes out really fast. We had a 30 minute wait at 8:30pm last Friday night. We were done eating by 9:45pm.

Here's what I remember ordering (for a party of 6):
- xiao long bao (skip it. they have no idea what they're doing here. as expected)
- bok choy with scallop sauce
- chow mein with beef (surprisingly delicious tender beef. I expected it to be stale)
- shiu mai
- green beans with garlic (fantastic)
- bbq pork buns a.k.a. cha siu bao (surprisingly authentic)
- sweet and sour pork 

Food came out piping hot and very flavorful and authentic enough. There's nothing that makes my skin crawl more than offensive adaptations attempted by capitalist America at the food of my motherland.

But I gotta say. I was impressed and YES I would eat here again.

Bill came out to about $22 per person.

I stayed at the Wynn Tower Suites, and was tired from exhibiting the show all day. So i decided to take the first restaurant near the tower suites. Ordered the following. Since i know it's probably not as authentic as i would like it to be so the basics should be easy enough for the chef to handle and me and my dad would have no problem enjoying the following 
1) Chicken Friend Rice 
2) Beef Chow Mien (oily) 
3) Garlic String Beans (oily) 

All around it was enjoyable spending $70 including tips on the above following with a coke and green tea, we thought that was the end of a basic and pricey PANDA express. Well I was wrong. It is 2:37am and i am still awake and dieing of thirst, my dad has a minor headache. I guess the MSG they put in the food was way too powerful. After 2 bottles of water and an orange juice i am still awake with the bad taste of MSG in my mouth. If your OK and not allergic to MSG this is place to go. I would think for the price they pay they can do better without artificial taste of MSG.
Just average service.  Made us (2people) wait 15 mins for a seat when plenty of seats were open.   Limited dim sum many so we ordered entrees.   Spring rolls were a little burned.

Beautiful decor:  red and gold with a mix of old and new.  But the food did not measure up to the decor and to my expectations.  I'm fortunate enough to live near a hub of great Asian restaurants and markets.  The food here basically tastes like what you get from Chinese takeout places.  Now I don't have an aversion to Chinese takeout, I enjoy it in fact.  But I really thought this place would be a little more special since I saw a large Chinese family partaking on a meal.  The food is mediocre and forgettable, but at least it's affordable (during lunchtime) and the service is pleasant.

I give it 3 stars for the food and 5 stars for the decor.

I knew what I was getting into when I heard we had reservations at the Wynn :)... We went there for Chinese New Year. There were seven of us so we ordered a bunch of dishes and got what we expected. Lamb chops, chicken fried rice, Chilean sea bass, duck, beef tenderloin, walnut shrimp, greens....etc. Red 8 is beautiful. Service is great and food was awesome. Prices were not as bad as we thought they would be for being on the strip.

Will be back for sure!

We had a delicious dinner in their semi-private room in the front of the restaurant. The service was pretty good, especially in light of the fact that our group of six was a few cocktails deep by the time that we were seated. We ordered mostly dim sum type food and everything was delicious. Nothing particularly stood out. The prices were reasonable and the wine list was good. We had three bottles and probably ten dishes and the bill came to $230 or something like that. Not bad for 6 people in Vegas.

Red 8 is quite possibly the best Chinese restaurant in Vegas. It is located in the Wynn and is spectacularly designed as the hotel is. The hostesses are always friendly and walk you themselves to the table. The foods impeccable. We always get the shrimp Chow Mein ($24) and and tried the Sweet and Sour Chicken tonight ($19). Both dishes were so delicious. The Chow Mein does only have 4 shrimp but it's Vegas so that's expected. The Sweet and Sour Chicken is plentiful and so good. The soft drinks are $4. This particular night we didn't have the best waiter but usually they are very attentive and helpful. I would definitely recommend this restaurant when you come to Vegas. It is totally worth the price.

i went here for lunch and the place was very quiet, the atmosphere was beautiful, and with all the sensory overload of las vegas, this place seemed like a little oasis!  so hip and great. the vegan menu was AMAZING.  everything i ate was DELISH and seriously so much fun!  .  

i had to take off one star for my friend, her noodle dish was good, but the noodles were inedible.  when we told the server she kind of just giggled and took the dish away.  in reality i was looking for either noodles to be re-made for her, OR money off the check.  my friend left hungry and somewhat disappointed. plus with the server just giggling - isn't that a little insulting?

ps this place is NOT CHEAP.  but the gunpowder tea is worth the full $5
Suckest Chinese food ever had. Nothing tastes right. A couple of boiled tofu with soy sauce cost 10 dollars. Will not ever return here.

My friend and I had given this place a first try since we were at the Wynn Hotel and it was a big "miss" for us on fulfilling our appetite. The service was noticeably slow. The food portion was disappointing for the price we paid for. 

Ambiance was semi-dressy and the food seemed more or less like a glorified Panda Express.

- Shiu Mai - Pork and Shrimp Dumplings 
- Mongolian Beef 
- Assorted BBQ Platter (Marinated Chicken, Roasted Duck, BBQ Pork)
- Braised E-Fu Noodles
- Combination Fried Rice

The Shiu Mai, mongolian beef and combination fried rice was the most appealing of our entire orders. Shiu Mai was the one that solely hit the spot. If it were not that expensive for 4 pcs, I'd ordered numerous orders of dim sum for the remainder of the night as my dinner. The mongolian beef and combination friend rice almost suppresed our hunger. 

The biggest disappointment was the Braised E-Fu Noodles which lacked any flavor and was just short of any enjoyment.

Overall, we paid a hefty bill in our attempt to suppress our hunger this night. I'd give this place a whirl if you are staying at the Wynn but not worth a cab fare, drive, or walk to eat at this place.

Some. Ice vegan dishes. Vegan siu Mai dumplings were good. Jade dumplings too. Unfortunately no vegan noodle soups. Service iffy. 

The vegan chicken lettuce wraps were fantastic. 

Unfortunately like all the restaurants near the casino area, the smoke wafts into the whole room. Almost ruins it.

ARE YOU SERIOUS? a 3 star on yelp? you've got to be kidding me.

as an indonesian chinese(who speaks mandarin) who grew up in singapore and had travelled to hong kong for the millionth time and been to most part of china, this restaurant offered just the best chinese food i'd had in america! (had to be more precise so my 5* rating would be valued)

yes some of them aren't authentic but screw it, because its shiu mai was fucking good. 

the last time i stayed at Wynn(which was last may/june), i was here about 2-3 times. this time, i was here for another 3 times, not including the dimsums we had for room service. we had our regular dimsum and i liked everything but cha siew bao(pork bun) because 1.i'd tasted better ones 2.it didn't taste like pork at all. i think there was something else mixed in there(human meat?) but it didn't taste good. one of my favorite dim sum, sesame rice ball, wasn't that good either. disappointed.

however, the har gow, siew mai, kway teow, century egg+pork floss congee(room service), can't remember a hundred other dim sum we had, but they were just 5*. i'd never even had that good a kway teow in singapore. 

THE CHILLY!! the chilly casted a spell on us. how can there be such a good chilly made? spicy and sweet at the same time. even better than the one i made. comparable to indonesian chilly. it was so good my korean friend and i each requested for some to be taken home. 

it's not over! i haven't mentioned the service yet! one of the korean lady server(i asked if she was japanese because she was so hospitable). everyone else was good but she was excellent.

Really beautiful room, just like everything at Wynn.  Pretty standard Pan Asian menu with some fun drinks.  You definitely pay for the address but it's worth it to be at Wynn and it's cheaper than a lot of the other restaurants in the area.

If you're too lazy to get your butt into your car or a taxi and drive into Chinatown, then I guess Red 8 would be a sufficient fix for Chinese food. The food is very Americanized but what more could you expect? The restaurant itself is very modern chic. Definitely not your typical Chinese hole-in-the-wall. On the smaller size in Las Vegas standards. The service was average. It felt like they were always in a hurry for some reason. We would only be able to ask for one thing before they walked off to get it. Why would you want to give yourself more work? 

Anyway, my family ordered many dishes including Mongolian Beef, Beef Chow Fun, etc. I was very hesitant and set the bar low so I ordered my own dinner entree, Pork & Preserved Egg Congee. $12 for a bowl of congee is a bit steep but we are at the Wynn!

It was a bit of a surprise. The congee was nice and thick, with good portions of the preserved duck egg and pork. The bowl itself was really big. I was expecting to finish it all myself but I had some left to share with the fam. I'd still definitely prefer to eat at a hole-in-the-wall for just as good quality at half the price.

TIP: They have brown rice!

Fantastic customer service, when it came down to one of the people in our party breaking a heel the waiter was down to find glue to help. 
But back to the . Loved all of it. I had the udon noodle  and a Thai tea. We rolled out of The Reve and were ready to chow down and Red 8 was a good choice. No complaints in the dinner party.

Red 8 has a nice atmosphere and the restaurant itself it's beautifully decorated. The service was also good. However, I was upset with the food during my experience. 

I ordered the crab Rangoon which had a strong fishy smell and taste to it. The texture of the filling did not seem authentic. I also got the shrimp and wonton noodle soup, and that also had an overwhelmingly fishy smell and taste. I only took one bite and asked for the check because I was scared to get food poisoning!
Hm. If u just want something to eat. Fare place to go. But speak loud, the young man here seems can't hear very clear, and don't expect to much about the food, just less tasty food.

Came here for a late lunch one day. The place was only half full and pretty quiet, which I really appreciated. We ordered vegetable steamed bun, har gow, egg noodle soup, and choi sum stir fried with garlic. Everything was really good, I especially liked the veggie steamed bun, I could have eaten just 10 of that and left this place happy. The egg noodle soup was really good too (it definitely satisfied my mom who was craving soup noodle the whole time we were in vegas!!). I would say this place is WAY better than Wazuzu in Encore. So if you're at Wynn or Encore and want quick Asian food fix, definitely go to this place over Wazuzu.

Service was quick, food was good but overpriced and certain things were a little bland or off. I ordered crispy mango scallops and the mango salsa was delicious but they certainly weren't crispy. Lettuce wraps were ok but a little bland. My hubby needed Asian food and liked it but I was just so so

I'll start by saying they have a good amount of stuff on the menu here from the Wynn Macau so the food is pretty authentic. 

My favorite dish here are the Hong Kong Crispy Noodles. The noodles are really good and they don't smother it in cheap xo sauce. 

The downside to this place is that they don't take reservations and they like to pretend they're busier than they actually are. I would recommend putting your name down, coming back, and not accepting their "you weren't back fast enough" excuse they might try to hand out (as in my case). Vegas is all about false scarcity. Don't take it! On the flip side, actual food service was very good. I would come here again!

I ordered the special dumpling noddle soup and to be honest, it wasn't all that special. It was pretty bland in my taste and overpriced! But then again...it IS vegas so you can't expect much. Overall experience is average.
Very decent Chinese food. Pricey for sure, so I'm not sure why it is $$ instead of $$$. Service + food + decor = 4 stars. Would be 5 if this really was '$$' - 11-20 bucks a person.

Red 8 was decent. All of the dim sum plates we had were great, but the entrees were just okay. The chive dumplings were so good! Seats weren't too comfortable, but otherwise a great atmosphere right on the edge of the casino.

Great tasting food and service. We walked in not expecting too much due to the nice decor but was really surprised by how this rivals some "authentic" Chinese cuisins inside the Wynn Casino.  If you don't want to travel to Chinatown for good food, come here. It's a bit pricier than your Chinatown restaurant but it's well worth it in my opinion.

Pricey? yes.  For 3 of us eating at ~3:30, our meal was $97.58 including tip -- that's an appetizer, 2 beverages, and 3 entrees.  But the portions were huge -- I think the 3 of us girls could have split an entree easily (but where's the fun in that?)  

I was interested in the Panang chicken noodle dish, thinking it would be an interesting variation of panang curry chicken.  No, the curry in panang curry comes from the "curry" part -- But, the waitress did say the sauce was a brown sauce after I asked for a little more detail, and I thought it was verrry tasty.  Like an 8 for me, yum. My friends stuck to more conventional chinese dishes of sweet and sour chicken + kung pao chicken.  I'd say those were tasty + flavorful, but probably not worth $20 (again, because I am cheap, not because they're bad).  I will say: man, the chicken satay was YUMMY.  The peanut sauce was a little thicker than I expected, but seriously tasted like the chefs ground up tons and tons and tons of peanuts right before sending it out. No lie.  Awesome.

If I won it big in Vegas + wanted good Asian food with a casual vibe, I'd for sure return.  Otherwise, I'm happy dining at fast food places along the way :)

Wynn's "casual" Chinese option. A regular spot for Wynn executives and serves a wide variety of Asian dishes. As with all Wynn restaurants the standard of quality and service are very high and the prices reflect it. I like the Singapore Vermicelli and the steamed veggies.
Delicious food with delicious vegan options. Very impressed with quality of food. Great for vegans & nonvegans alike! Great staff & great atmosphere!

My go to at Wynn. Their orange beef is fantastic - reminds me of great NY Chinese food. They do a banana spring roll type dessert that is not to be missed ! Service is always fast and friendly. Give it a try, you'll be glad you did.

I come to Las Vegas often 2 to 3 times a month and always eat here once a month at least. The service has gone down tremendously I waited for hours to have my food and it was ridiculous. If the kitchen is backed up is on the waiter to come and tell me so I choose to wait 1-2 hrs to eat or leave. Give me an appetizer or something but don't make me and my date suffer for 2.5 hrs and still not have it ready. It is unacceptable.

Thank you Chef Joshua for a great experience. Food, service and ambiance was spectacular. The dumplings and the sea bass was exceptional- so much flavor! What a great dinner to start our evening. Can't wait to come back!

We had pork buns, sweet and sour chicken, and black bean sautéed spare ribs and they were all good.  I like the ambiance and location, but I was hoping to be wow'd more by the taste at the prices.  The portions were good size and it came with rice.  It gets a 3.5 stars rounding down since I wouldn't rush back.

I went here for dinner two nights in a row, the food and service was impeccable.

The roasted pork belly was to die for. It had the crispiness and just the right amount of fat.  I don't normally like eating pork belly because it's very fatty, but I did it.  The flavor was perfect.  The choy sum stir fried with garlic was delicious, even my daughter enjoyed it.  I also ordered the prawns with eggs, knowing that I can't go wrong since my kid loves eggs. The prawns are giant looking... 

The wait staff was super friendly and the ambiance was worth the price I paid for.  We had to wait but it was worth it.  I asked the hostess if she can get a chair for my daughter, since she can't sit in the gaming area. 

I will definitely come back when we visit in the future.

Probably the least-pretentious, most reasonably-priced and easiest to get into restaurant at the Wynn. Solid Chinese and Malaysian food on the fairly expansive menu. 

I had the vegan cashew "chick'n," which was actually Gardein...a weird sort of fake-meat that tasted exactly like real chicken. My friend had Pad Thai, which he also said was excellent.

The ambiance is OK -- sort of Asian Brothel chic, with some casino views. One side looks out toward the VIP towers, so it's fun to watch the high-end hookers come and go.

I will DEFINITELY come here again.

Lunch with my hot wife.
The dim sum was delicious we had several kinds and everything was prepared perfectly. The service was excellent and the price was reasonable. I would definitely recommend this to anyone in the area where the special trip just to try the tasty delicacies.
Amazing place.  Stylish.  Clean. Fresh.  Food is amazing and the portions are huge.  Tables are not crammed together.  Wish there were a few more pork dishes

We have been here a few times in the last couple of years. Food is consistently great! If you like calamari switch it up and try the deep fried soft shelled crab (it's spicy but you should be able to get it mild if you ask). 

Sometimes the line to get in is long but once seated the service is fast and friendly.

I would've have given this place 4 or 5 stars because the food was delicious.  However, the food coming back up a few hours later was not so delicious.  

My husband and I stayed at the Wynn since we had a 4 day weekend (Thanksgiving weekend).  On Saturday night, we decided to have some Chinese food.  I read the reviews and looked at the pictures on here and it looked great.  My husband was craving for Chinese food also.  We didn't have reservations and arrived around 6:30pm.  We were greeted and seated promptly.  The place wasn't crowded, but had a handful of groups already dining.  

We ordered 4 items to share since a reviewer stated that they were small portions, which wasn't the case for us.  Didn't look like they were small portions.  I guess for me, the portions were just right.  We ordered the Roasted Duck, Beef with Noodles (it was very similar to Pad See Ew - Thai noodle dish), BBQ pork and Shrimp Fried Rice, and Soft Shell Crab.  Everything was great.  Food was good, very flavorful and so good.  Wait staff was great, friendly, and attentive.  

Then a couple of hours later, while in our hotel room, my husband started vomiting.  He threw up about 10 times within 13 hours.  It was just awful.  I don't recommend eating the Soft Shell Crab.  I think that is what did it to us since that was the only one we shared.
Don't get their milk tea. Taste like water, the boba taste like glue soaked in water.

Stopped in here for dinner as it was located closest to my hotel room. Compared to other restaurants in the Wynn-Encore compound this one lacks. The food is hit or miss; the service was slow and lackluster (they were not that busy) and the cost is high. There are better options in Vegas and even within the Wynn-Encore indoor mall.
Beautiful and the food is real good.. must try

overpriced; i've tasted better. the spring roll and potsticker was mediocre. I can get the same taste at a take-out. the Thai Basial Beef was good but the white rice was hard (i prefer softer white rice). And $6 for each plate of dim sum, well i at least expected it to be HOT. I had to send it back to be microwaved because low and behold, it was cold (my fried mixed dumpling). The fried taro cake was good but nothing so out of the ordinary. It was $5 for Coke... outrageous. My lunch for two, 2 entrees and 2 dim sum, 1 drink, 1 water, was $58. I will be going to ChinaTown next time.

Had the Taiwanese Seabass in three cups sauce and off the dim sum menu: steamed bbq pork buns, shrimp chive dumplings, and pork won tons. All excellent, esp loved the buns and the dumplings. Service wasn't great- I'd say 3 stars- but overall happy with this place. Also got the lychee jasmine tea with boba and sparkling lemonade. Yum! Addendum- service now at 2 stars. Order was supposed to come with rice- I asked if he could do half brown half white and he said no. Ok Fine. Then he didn't bring it, so we asked and he said he could add it to the order for us. We were done and thus we declined to find out he charged us $2 for it. So irritating and rude!

Only went here because we were staying at Encore. The food is not terrible, but overpriced for what you get. You can find better, more authentic versions of everything on nearby Spring Mountain Road. Service is friendly but slow. Decor is nice.

Stopped in here for a quick meal after a shopping excursion in the Wynn and left somewhat disappointed. The turnip cakes were some of the best and the Cantonese dumplings were delish but the dan dan noodles, which they note is a signature dish was beyond bizarre.  It came dry with very little by way of meat or flavor and you have the option of adding broth.  Well the broth did not add anything.  Blech.

oooooohhh why Wynn, why?

The presentation is beautiful. Vibrant red and gold! Silk and Satin! Comfy booths! Why does your food taste so bad?

Let me break it down:

Beef Satay- lukewarm, beef was very chewy and grisly, good peanut sauce but nothing special, needed more spice.
Singapore Rice- taste like curry powder tossed with rice. woopie.
Phad Thai Noodles- smelt like Alpo. Taste was mild, shrimp were bland
Kung Pao Chicken- ok, really saucy and very few peanuts, chili oil was separating

THE ONLY really good thing I ate there were their fried turnip cakes with taro. these hold a wow factor that nothing else on the menu can bring!
We ordered two more after we tried the entrees. 

The food was so disappointing that we gave all our left overs to a homeless man who was sitting near the Hooters Casino. Is that mean?

Hands down my FAVORITE restaurant in Vegas. I eat here EVERY TIME I'm here. Everything is delicious and they have milk tea, but ask for less ice because if you're a sipper, it gets watered down kinda quick. Fried rice is AMAZING. EVERYTHING is good.

If you are in the mood for century egg congee and some dim sum after a night of gambling at the Wynn,  this is the place to go.  The congee is not the greatest but comforting enough with the right consistency. I also had the Shumai which was surprisingly ok. Late night dim sum?  This is the place!  I saw some tables have their fill of fried rice and sweet&sour pork and they look yummy.

We were walking around the Wynn which though beautiful and stunning, it had a weird vibe. It was really empty while we were there, which is strange because it was a holiday weekend. We decided to have dinner there and Red 8 seemed like a good option (and one of the more affordable ones). We went up to the host and asked for a table for 2 and were so surprised to hear that it was a 20 minute wait. The hotel was so quiet and empty! We played a few slots to kill some time and when we went back only 15 minutes later, we were seated right away ... in a half empty restaurant! That already had my eyes rolling and then the rest of the night seemed to drag. It took awhile to get our order placed, waited some more for the food to come out, our waiter seemed to disappear when we wanted our check and we had to ask 2 different people before it finally came. It just didn't have the service I'd expect from a nicer hotel. And I really don't know what they were trying to prove with the wait-time when the restaurant was half empty.

Now as for the food, I had the dan dan noodles with pork which was just OK. The portion could have been bigger (compared to my husband's similar-to-spicy-Thai basil noodles which was a large portion) and I barely had any pork.

I was in Vegas a few weeks ago and got the chance to try 3 Asian casual dining restaurants at a couple of Vegas hotels - Red 8 (Wynn), Beijing 99 (Caesar's Palace), and Wazuzu (Encore).

Out of the 3, I would rank them the following in terms of authentic flavors and yumminess - 

1. Red 8 (yummiest)
2. Beijing 99 (delish)
3. Wazuzu (boo!)

I would rank them like this in terms of value

1. Beijing 99 (good selection of entrees and price range between $12-$19)
2. Red 8 (also good selection of entrees and prices between $12-$19)
3. Wazuzu (OVERPRICE ALERT!)

Overall, I would return to Red 8 and Beijing 99 for solid PF Chang-like food with PF Chang-like prices.  

The chicken stirfries at Red 8 hit the spot in the couple of dishes we ordered.  The sweet and sour pork packed a vinegary punch.  The portions are well-sized, and the wait staff was friendly.  Best of all, the entrees are mostly under $21.  That's great compared to other Vegas restaurants that have $40 entrees!

Other things on the menu that we liked - the wonton noodles, and the dim sum.

I'm sure there are other better Chinese options off the strip, but Red 8 is a solid Chinese bet if you're stuck on the Vegas strip without a car to get to decent Asian places in Vegas.

If you're okay with mediocre Chinese food with great ambiance and impeccable service, you will fair well here.  My bf & I were hungry, and this place looked enticing thanks to the interior design.  We may come back again for convenience sake, but it isn't at the top of our list.  Coming from the bay area and growing up Chinese, the food here is decent but far from authentic and lacks great flavors.  

Mykl was our friendly waiter and delivered great service to us.  We had a couple bottles of sake which did not disappoint, ox tail soup, bok choy with scallop sauce, cold cucumbers and chicken and jelly fish.  

The ox tail soup was the best.  It was pretty simple with green onions floating around and a decent portion of oxtail.  The meat didn't fall off the bone though.  The baby bok choy was okay but the scallop sauce wasn't live with flavors.  The same went for the chicken and jellyfish.  This dish had light flavors to it but once again nothing exciting.  The chicken was soft and the jelly fish was fresh.  I didn't care for the cold cucumbers much.  I thought they would be more soy sauce and garlicky, but they had a ginger sweetness to them I didn't care for.  My bf liked them fine though.

Honestly, PF Chang's serves better Chinese food, but I'm sure there are other things on the menu I might like better.  The red and black decor with dramatic lighting is absolutely top notch design, but that and the service here is all you will find to be exceptional.

They have vegan dim sum!  since going vegan I've been wanting dim sum. They have a few dishes for us vegans. I got the jade & the bok choy with garlic sauce to make it vegan. It was so good. I love that they have a separate menu for vegans at the wynn. The server was very knowledgeable in what to substitute to fit my needs. Must try if you want good Asian food.

Excellent Dim Sum

The Wynn has many good dining options.  I was not expecting Red 8 to be one of them.  Located just off the casino floor, Red 8 offers Chinese and South Asian cuisine with an extensive menu of appetizers, entrees, and drinks.  The decor is fun and clean.  The service is friendly and helpful.  

We decided to order from their dim sum menu.  The shumai were steamed and delicious with a warm center of shrimp.  The BBQ pork steamed buns were superb with a great savory sweetness.  The almond shrimp balls were unusual but tasty.  The steamed shrimp buns were delicious with a nice salty center of shrimp and a sweet starchy taste on the outside.  The Cantonese dumplings were perfect with pork and cabbage.  

We left very satisfied.  I will definitely be back!
Went there again for lunch. Food was delivered not as fast as before but the service staff aware of it and kept track on our orders. Managers are nice to check on us. Service are super

The amazing congee they serve as part of room service at the Wynn is NOT the same as the one from Red 8! In other words, don't order the congee from this place but do get it in your room. 

As for the beef noodles, the broth was ok , but the noodles texture and taste was all wrong.

Finally, the pork/shrimp dim sum thing was terrible.

The plus is that they are open late and service is good.

Sufficed to say, I will never return. Going to this restaurant was by pure accident.

This is probably the best bargain in the Wynn. Ironically, I've stayed here a couple of times, but did not try Red 8 until this trip when I stayed at the Mandarin. Go figure.  Steve Wynn's Macau location gets some love here on the menu in the form of some nice noodle dishes. Standouts for me were the cold chicken and jellyfish appetizer, and my Traditional Beijing Pork Noodles. I like that this place isn't stuffy, just good food at reasonable (for Vegas) prices.

Walking in this place smelled amazing.  The food wasn't bad but I just wasn't WOW'ed for a Vegas restaurant in the Wynn.  It had a menu with similar items you see at any local small end Chinese restaurant but the quality was definitely light years better than that, but our server didn't make recommendations for items either which might have better highlighted the full potential of this place.  She also was not readily available after placing our order.  Overall - the best standard dish Chinese-American/Asian fusion menu I've had, but skip-able on the Vegas dining scene, & for the price!!

After a night of partying at Tao, my friends and I decided to continue our Asian theme and headed downstairs from our room at the Wynn to Red 8 for some dim sum and other assorted Asian delights.

After opening the menu, my eyes almost started bleeding. Combination fried rice $25?!? One plate of normal dim sum $6?! I know it's the Wynn but come on! At these prices we could've just ate at The Buffet and gotten a lot of similar quality food for less.

Since we already sat down and committed to the restaurant, we decided to stay and order. To minimize the damage, we ordered just 3 dim sum plates (cha shu bao, shanghai dumplings, and fried taro balls) and two dishes (broccoli beef and sesame chicken). Growing up in the bay area, I've had my fair share of good Chinese food, and let me tell you, this was not it. The cha shu bao (bbq pork buns) were soggy and the filling was an unidentifiable paste with a few bits of meat. The Shanghai dumplings had no soup in them. The broccoli beef was mediocre.

If you want good Chinese food in Las Vegas, DO NOT go here. There must be better options elsewhere on the strip. This restaurant definitely caters to rich people who don't know much about Asian food.

I came here with my in-laws who were visiting from India and were so freakin' tired of pasta, raw vegetables, and cheese.  Oh, America.  I tried to tempt them with Japanese food at Mizumi but raw fish wasn't up their alley, either.  We stumbled across Red 8 and their eyes lit up.  Pan-Asian, it was!

As a vegan, I was absolutely delighted to be dining at a Wynn restaurant, knowing there would absolutely be delicious food for me to eat.  I started with a soy Thai Iced Tea and I nearly lost my mind, it was so good.  I ordered two vegan dim sums, the white lotus and jade dumplings, at the waitress' suggestion.  I don't remember what's actually in them (spinach?  mushrooms?) but they were both fantastic.  For my main, I had the Vegan Tofu Shiitake.  It was okay, but a little boring!  We had some hot chili paste with the dumplings so I liberally spooned that over my food to give it some oomph.  Even boring tofu and mushrooms can still hit the spot, and I left quite full.

My in-laws loved their food and everyone had a great meal.  The prices are exorbitant but nothing worse than any place else in the area.  Next time I'm in the area and craving something similar, I think I'll have to check out Wazuzu.  Similar menu, but more vegan options (including sushi!).
This place inside the Wynn is actually pretty good. The ambiance is nice and the food was tasty. It was just expensive for chinese food, but at least it wasn't too americanized.

I highly recommend.  The food was great, the portions generous, and you couldn't ask for better service.  Also, the decor is really cool and classy.    They have a nice blend of authentic Chinese and American-style Chinese.  Finally, the price is great. I would expect to pay twice the price for half the quality around here.

Despite some of the stinky reviews by yelpers, I think this is one of those places you'll either love/hate depending on what you decide to order.   

please try:
-Chinese Lettuce w/Preserved Bean Curd (sounds strange, but it is fantastic)
-Steamed Chilean Seabass
-Curried Singapore Vermicelli
-any of the fried rice dishes

please avoid:
- Ma Po Tofu (not spicy, bland)
- dim sum (overpriced, go down Spring Mtn Rd. and you'll see why)

Red 8 is a bit pricey, but if you're staying at the Wynn and are in the mood for pan-Asian, it's one of the more reasonable places to eat.

My in laws can't go more than a day without Asian foods so it made sense why we found ourselves in Red 8 for dinner on our first night in Vegas. 

Every item was expected to be overpriced and underwhelming since we were dining in some fancy hotel. That expectation was certainly met. $20 plus for tasteless Penang noodles. $9 for three soupless soup dumplings. Not a single dish was passable in taste (let alone value). 

Unless you are stuck like me having to go with whatever your laws were craving - avoid avoid avoid. Save your wallet and your stomach.

Great place just inside the casino at Wynn hotel.
Great service!
I was really happy with my hot tea...The OOLONG tea have a great cafeine KIK, Better than Red Bull!
I got the prawn...were huge...$22
MAKE SURE TO ORDER THE COCONUT ICE CREAM!
You will be dreaming to come back and have one!

The Chinese believe that the number 8 is good luck representing prosperity. The color red also represents power and fortune. OK the true story behind Red 8 is that only certain dishes are amazing and the rest are average Chinese food. If this restaurant were a little cheaper and located somewhere other than the Wynn, I would rave. But it is in the Wynn and people (I'm people) expect a lot. I've eaten here twice, the first time I got something simple like Sesame Chicken or something. It was good but nothing amazing. Just the chicken in the sauce on the rice. You could've gotten the same at P.F. Chang's.

However, the second time I went I said screw this. My co-workers kept talking about how good the place was so I'm like ok let's give this place a real try. I ordered the jellyfish appetizer. DELICIOUS! Best I've had. Try it, it's not as scary as it sounds. Jellyfish is awesome and they make the best. Second, I had the seabass. It was pan fried in like a tempura bredding but spicy like it sat with some jalapenos for a while. Great. I love seabass and this is some of the best I've had. The difference was night and day. I guess the key to this place is order the most expensive thing on the menu. Actually I think someone at my table said they do that everywhere they go. How retarded! But I guess in some cases it works. Like misplaced little Chinese eateries. Also, too much red and black decor. I started to feel like I was in a Samuri movie.

Decided to try this place since we stayed at Encore and it was convenient. My two friends ordered the beef noodle soup and I ordered the sweet and sour chicken with a side of brown rice. Everything tasted good, but I don't think there was anything special about the food where I'd want to go out of my way to come back. The sweet and sour chicken came out crispy and fresh and it wasn't overly sweet to me. It had the right amount of tangy-ness you'd expect. The beef noodle soup was also good, the noodles weren't overcooked and the beef was tender. Service was good and the restaurant was very clean. Prices are a little steep (came out to around $25 for my sweet and sour chicken with a side of rice) but it's Vegas. Overall a solid 3/5.

Good food and ok service.  Tables are close together to fit more people like Sardines. 
We had the Oxtail soup, not that good . The steemed rice was perfect lol. .the Mongolian Beef was also good,  the Cashew Chicken was bland 
The price was too high  for  the service and the food quality and quantity.

Sub-par, at best. 

The chicken satay and Mongolian beef didnt seem to be a good quality - they were gristly and lacking flavor. 
The only thing slightly enjoyable was the green beans with ginger, green beans were fresh.

Service - wait staff never asked if we were ok or enjoying our food - maybe they know?  Even when we asked for the bill, the waiter came back, not with the bill, but to try to convince us of dessert..um no thanks....

I would say that there are many other restaurants out there that will be enjoyable.

Super cozy place with nice romantic decor not to bright inside and service was fast and friendly. The jade dumplings are so great I had 3 order and the tofu dish with vegetables were just okay but would not recommend. Will go again but will only order the dumplings.

High quality food, nice service and for a nice restaurant like this one, the price is set at a pretty low rate, will diffidently go back again next time when I visit Vegas.

I love the three cup sea bass

Long wait to be seated and food to be served. (i don't know if there's discrimination involved, hey were Asian, its an Asian resto. LOL)  But food taste good though. Shumai was good. Congee - definitely  a hangover remover. and its not just a "$$" ill say its a "$$$$" for some reason. We just ordered some of this, some of that. and kapow! are bill was around $230ish..  and lastly. There is a SERVICE CHARGE and it's separate from GRATUITY. like wtf?!!

Came to the Wynn for the buffet but with a 2 hour wait, we decided to eat here instead. Service was ok but a little slow. We came with a group of 8. We ordered around 10 dishes total and asked the server if it was enough food. He assured us it would be but alas it was not. The food itself is pretty tasty but the portion size left us all wanting for more. Pan fried noodles and the roast duck were the two dishes that particularly stuck out in my mind.  It might be unfair to compare this place to more authentic chinese restaurants in LA but can't help it, sorry.

The price is not worth the quality. When you pay $8.00 min for a plate dim sum you expect a lot more than what I got. The food was Mediocre at best. And what is up with charging $7.5 per person for tea? WTF!!!!!

After hearing so many good things about the Wynn I expected more from the food at this restaurant, and the service really sucked. They sat us right in front of the place in the restaurant and pretty much forgot about us. I had to turn around and flag the waiters down twice for refills and then again for the check. This was strange as the place was pretty dead.

It's not super pricy, given its location. The service was kind and attentive. Food quality was above average for the menu items, and it came out relatively quickly. The food portions were also a good size. Overall, I enjoyed it and I'd recommend it to anyone craving Asian cuisine in Vegas.

It's amazing how after two years, Red 8 hasn't changed anything about how they train their staff!  The service was bad the first time we came here - we actually walked out after ten minutes since no one came to ask us for a simple drink order or even acknowledge our existence.  There was a long line outside but lots of empty tables inside; they just couldn't get their act together about bussing the tables!

This time, we got seated immediately and quickly got drink service.  Only four other tables were occupied, a couple of tables already had their dim sum order, so we figured it was good to get there at opening.  WRONG!  Even with more than 3 waiters and a few more men walking around in black tees - no idea what they were since they enjoyed chatting and laughing amongst themselves but not really seat or serve anyone.  At one point, the host was pouring water for guests!  Beats the hell out of me what the other five men and one woman staff were doing!

Our waiter, an Asian guy was good and did the best he could even though it looked like he was out of breath trying to get to every table on our side of the restaurant.  It's not a big restaurant.  They were just inefficient in service.  They sat a party of five at a square table for four and a party of three at a booth where no one actually say on the booth but just on three chairs around the booth.  Go figure!

Dim sum is the easiest way to get your food FAST.  That includes congee!  However, it was a slight wait and some of the food wasn't even warm!  It baffled and annoyed me.  What's worst then eating bad food is food that is not warm!!  The food is tasty but I expected more.  No I didn't expect to have the best dim sum I have ever had but I did expect a higher standard here.  After all, the Wynn is supposed to take care of the serious high rollers and we know just how many Asians are so.  

The soy bean milk here is not sweetened which sucks.  We (Asians) all drinks sweetened soy milk and if not sweetened, given syrup on the side to add.  Sugar does not melt and no one adds bloody syrup to soy milk!!

BTW, don't order the hainanese chicken rice!  I had the chicken rice (room service) and the rice isn't flavorful enough, the soup tastes weird, chicken is dry and the chilli they use is out of a bottle you can buy from the store (sambal olek).

What a disappointment.  I won't return or test my luck again.

Not great, not bad.  Pleasant, but unmemorable.

There was about a 15-minute wait at 1:30 in the afternoon.  The atmosphere is lacking something, maybe a soul.  But, like everyone else we encountered at Wynn, the people were very friendly.

The veggie spring rolls were fried, which turned the insides to mush.  They came with a very brown sauce, which tasted like brown.

We shared the Mongolian beef, which I really liked.  It had a nice kick to it which my "no spicy!" wife was able to tolerate.

Service was friendly, but the spring rolls came out after the entree.

One appetizer, one entree, and two soft drinks set us back $48, including tip.  I wouldn't call this a great value for the money.

I'm gonna keep this short:

The service at Red 8 is amazing - 5 stars for all of the friendly people who work there! Other than that, though, Red 8 is basically like a fancier P.F. Chang's...which, in turn, is a fancier Panda Express. 
 
This place is worth checking out only if all of the following apply:
1) You're staying at the Wynn.
2) You're reeeeally craving Asian food. Like, really.
3) You don't mind paying well over $10 for noodles.
I always get the Kung Pao Chicken. Which is absolutely delicious. The service is good too. My only issue is like most casino restaurants its overpriced

Two words: vegan dim sum.  Oops, that's three.  Anyway, they have it, and it's delicious.  But it's pricey.  Very pricey. 

Went with a friend and sampled 4 different dishes, two from the dim sum menu (jade dumplings and tofu shumai), and two entrees (Gardein "chicken" lettuce wraps and tofu shiitake stir fry.  Every thing was so tasty, especially the dumplings.  Seasonings were right on; super flavorful.  The stir fry came with Chinese broccoli and American? broccoli and BROWN RICE! yay.  

The service was pretty terrible though.  We didn't even get water until after we already had our meal, and it was never really clear who our server was.

The atmosphere is great, the food is great; but at these prices, I'd expect better service.

Ok i have to be honest I am shocked that this level of quality is served at a steve wynn resort. The meal was comped but seriously this place was horrible. Panda express would be an improvement over this place. The bill was 130 for one person for lunch. Of course i had leftovers to take to pops but I felt like he might feel as though I was trying to poison him. I ordered the cantonese pot stickers to start. You could do better in the frozen section at costco. Next up I opted for the upgraded beef dish which is served table side on a sizzling platter it was like pepper beef sirloin or something like that. Really boring dish no imagination. was funny when i was ordering the waiter suggests i upgrade even further to kobe beef,I said well you probably wont get the benefit if its covered in a sauce,he says I will,even though i had a 200 comp and would not have had to pay for it I didn't do it. I asked him how much would it cost ,he says let me look on the menu,after we look together he cant find it he estimates it to cost around 90 dollars,like i said it would have been comped but it seemed too egregious to me. Next I ordered the sweet and sour chicken,total crap again you could do much better at panda express or costco. And lastly I ordered a bbq pork and shrimp combo fried rice,this was the best dish of all and I suspect that it is served regularly at the CCDC on fried crap night. In conclusion im glad i had  the comp but i still had to tip for 20 bucks ,its not the servers fault so i always take care of them. The server was very nice actually. Steve must be losing his taste as well as his vision because anyone who would rate this anything but touristy garbage food is on the payroll.

I know why people come here...it's because they want soup and they're staying at Encore or Wynn.  The soup here is terrible!  No flavor what so ever and service isn't all that great either.  When they are busy, they completely aren't attentive at all.  We had to asked 2-3 times to get our waiter, I don't understand why the other employee there didn't want to help us.  She said your waiter, will be right there.  It was the same way for our bill.  Took forever.  We avoid coming here for hungover food with our friends.  Pricey for something that isn't so great...is definitely a no thank you after 3 tries!  The food isn't consistent at all.  Dislike places that can't cook and just add spicy or sweeter to the broth.

Convenience won't make me think it is better.  Rather drive or cab it to a better place.

I could've given 5 stars but the chicken feet on the dimsum menu was tough. The flavor was there but tough. Ordered siu mai, shrimp dumplings, from the dimsum menu.... all good.
I recommend The beef tendon egg noodle soup - so tasty and flavorful - real authentic chinese beef noodle soup taste. The Kungpao shrimp was good as well. The hot and sour soup was a little too sour for me. Otherwise, not bad at all.
Very confusing...their Dan Dan Mien tasted like a Pad Thai, and how is it possible to make a hot & sour soup taste like tomato bisque???

Decided to try something different and had an excellent dinner. We got a couple of dishes and split them. Had a duck dish, orange beef and another thai dish. All three were excellent. Great atmosphere, really beautiful restaurant. Service was friendly and fast. The seating was both smaller tables and communal. They had a good selection on the menu and they have a dim sum menu that my daughter was excited about. Prices were a little high but not crazy especially for Vegas. We  really enjoyed the duck dish the best. It was served with Asian pancakes and was very memorable.

Went here with a couple of friends from out of town. We chose this place because it was almost 11:00pm and most of the other restaurants in the Wynn were getting ready to close (This is Vegas for God's sake!!! Why do these places close so early on a Thursday night???) We were seated within 5 minutes in a nice private dining area. All we had to do is close the curtain and it would be a good private dining experience! Well, somewhat private. It kind of felt like we were birds in a bird cage, since it literally was a round cage, where people on the outside can see in. Wait staff were mostly expressionless, like they were waiting for their shift to end so they can go home. 

We ordered some dim sum, and since it was getting late, I didn't want to eat anything heavy, so I got the Gardein Cashew Chick'n, Celery, Mushrooms & Ginger. Tastes just like chicken! This place is pretty pricey - $9 for each dim sum dish. So total came to just over $100 for what amounted to be a light snack. No bang for the buck here. Maybe I'll come back and treat someone here (if they pay!!)

I stopped coming to eat here about 2 years, tried this time because we lived in Wynn and not much choice here for breakfast. They probably changed the chef, I can see a lot improvement in the flavor. I love the roast duck without bone for appetizer. their stir fired dish, congee and noodle etc. are way much better in taste than before. The only thing I can complain is their tea selection is really poor.

A disappointing experience. We ordered the walnut prawns, which were dry and lacked flavor. The service was poor and our waiter did not check in with us nor refill our drinks during the duration of our meal. When he finally checked back, we had long finished the other dish, cashew chicken (which was okay), and had been surfing on our smart phones for 10 or so minutes. He then offered to get us another dish and we asked for him to take the walnut prawns (which we ate less than a third of) off the bill. This took another 10-15 minutes apparently to get his managers approval. The service was poor, the food average at best and it was somewhat pricey for what we got.

We dine here frequently as we are always visiting Vegas. This is one of my favorite restaurants but I had a bad experience here today- I have a severe allergy to onions and the waiter took the order correctly but the chef decided to cook my food with onions and what looks like tried to pick them out but they were still there. Long story short my throat started closing and I found a few of the onions in my beef hor fun. I requested for the manager to come so I could address the issue- was that a mistake. She looked at me like I was in the wrong and the waiter even said the kitchen made a mistake. Nonetheless she didn't apologize- nor try to remedy the issue, I hope they don't make this a common practice because I will stop coming here if this is the direction they are going to treat repeat clients.

I love the location of this restaurant. Wynn is one of my favorite hotels and the atmosphere and vibe is great!
I wasn't thrilled worth the service, very slow to take our order and then get the check at the end. If they were busy, I'd understand but they have a whole 5 tables there. 
I also didn't like that the food wasn't spread out. They brought soup and appetizers out at the same time and before we could even finish, the main course came out. Big minus. I like my food to be timed a bit better. 
We ordered the shrimp dim sum and the crab Rangoon as appetizers, both were delicious. The hot and sour soup was very flavorful and had a nice kick to it. 
As main course, it was suggested to get one dish to share since portions are large. The chefs special included seared scallops so we went with it. It is not a dish to share. 6 small scallops were served with a small salad and brown rice. I wasn't thrilled with the scallops. They didn't have much flavor and he side salad had no dressing. As a whole, I wasn't impressed. I heard great things, so I wouldn't mind trying it again with more traditional dishes.

I have been dying to come here during my last few visits to the Wynn. There is a long wait for Red 8 but the food is good and the prices aren't bad. It is an above average Chinese restaurant as far as quality and ambiance.

I've always enjoyed the Chinese, Asian fusion that is offered at Red 8.
I've probably ate here way over 10 times and each time had no complaint.
The food is usually quick so if you are planning to do casual dining and is in a impatient mood go to Red 8.

My favorite by far is the Chilean sea bass in a light soy base sauce with thinly sliced green onions. 
The dim sums during breakfast and brunch is great. I believed we've ordered and tried everything on their menu and some were good, not so good, and bad.

The service is average. There decor is quite unique and RED.

I mainly go there for the Chilean sea bass.

I came here because I was super excited about the vegan dim sum..... I appreciate the vegan options, however the ambiance, staff and overall taste is lacking. The chairs are sticky and the booth is scratchy and sunken in. The hostess was having a bad night or something because she did not have a happy or inviting attitude and made us wait 30 minutes even though there were CLEARLY open tables. And when I say clearly I mean you can walk around this place and see everything so... You lied.... And you did it just to be rude... it was clear. The two stars are only being given because you offer vegan food and I feel that is a step in the right direction. 

Basically my money and time would have been better spent getting a vegan slice of pizza at the place by the Mandalay bay or a nothing salad at an upscale place at the Aria.

Red 8 is a Chinese restaurant in the Wynn Hotel.  I ordered Kung Pao chicken, which was very tasty, although not as spicy as it might have been.  The portion was a good size and the ingredients were fresh.
I gave Red 8 a 3 star mainly because it was so overpriced - $19 for a dish that costs $9 anywhere else is problematic.
Pretty good quality and reasonable price since we are talking about the restaurant at Wynn.

My goto place for Hong Kong regional style dining. This is as authentic as it gets outside of Asia for true "local" Hong Kong crispy beef noodles, chicken feet, and siao long bao (soup dumplings).

Regional delights are also good, with Singaporean style chicken satay, Singapore street rice noodles, Cantonese roast duck, and traditional Hong Kong style wonton mien.
