The only thing lacking, which is a weird thing to say since I'm touting authenticity, is the same sometimes-annoying Hong Kong service. Sometimes they fuck up your order and the one thing you've been craving some turns gets lost in limbo.

Still, I'll take that over better service with shitty food.

Loved this not so pretentious noodle house at the Wynn.  The soft noodle chow main was excellent and also loved their Mongolian beef.  Good thing I decided to judge for myself instead of listening to some of the yelp reviews.  A little on the pricey side but you're in Vegas, so that's the norm.  You're certainly not going to get pricing like off the strip.  Service was on point, we got our food quickly, and the waiter checked on us often and kept our waters filled.  We pretty much tried all the standard Chinese fair so I can't speak to the dim sum menu.  Will give it another try the next time I stay at the Wynn.
Stopped into this restaurant impromptu...  Service was good, a bit slow to get food to table but food was superb.

I really wanted to like this place.  I ordered the Wonton Noodle Soup in hopes of curing a crucial hangover.  The soup was average.  A little too fatty for my taste - i could see a film of it floating on top!  I tried a bite of the Mongolian Beef dish, NOT GOOD.  Way too oily and tooooooo sweet.  The only semi decent dish I tried was the taro cake from the dim sum portion of the menu. Oh and don't even get me started on the service.  The waiter was soooo slow!!!  We asked for the check and 20 minutes later, got nothing.  I finally had to get up to find our waiter and even then, I STILL couldn't find him.   I had to ask a random waitress to get our check.  We could have pulled a dine and dash on his ass and he probably would be never have noticed.  Horrendous service and very overpriced for the quality of food.  Overall a bad experience.

This restaurant is over priced and extremely shitty quality. I ordered the cashew chicken (vegan) for 17$ and it was so bland. The sauce wasn't good, there were huge chunks of celery which would've been fine had they not been raw or maybe sliced more thin and  the fake chicken was dry (HOW DO YOU EVEN FUCK UP FAKE CHICKEN!?!) I ate like two bites of it and when asked how it was I told my waiter it was extremely disappointing and I didn't want it. My boyfriend still paid for it and I left hungry and upset.

 I was excited because I know the Wynn has vegan options but NO THANKS, never again.

A Vegas-style P.F. Chang's.  Woopty-fricken-do.  

Looks nice from the outside but nothing special on the inside.  When you sit down, all of the chairs are rickety...they rock back and forth when you move.  

Food was average.
Overpriced.
Service was slow and they didn't seem to care about your requests.

Don't even bother.  The Wynn made a bad choice here.

Took a friend there for dinner as were just wandering around. Walked in without reservation around 8:00p on a Saturday and they were very accommodating.  Were seated and did not have anyone address our table for at least 5-8 mins, food was slow coming out, but very tasty.  Felt the table arrangement was too close as we could hear everything the next table was saying and they were't loud.

I would recommend,but for a casual dinner.  This is not one for a romantic setting if that is what you want.

Located just off the blackjack tables at the Wynn Hotel, Red 8 is beautifully decorated and the food is high end.  Not a hole-in-the-wall messy restaurant with fully authentic tasting food, but more of an Americanized version of delicious Chinese.  Which is sometimes better on the stomach, if you know what I mean!  Read the full review on my blog.

ehh it wasn't the best but not the worst.
I had the monoglian beef

Great food!  Don't let other reviews sway you with the words "authentic".  It is Americanized Asian food.  I hate it when people try to call things like sweet and sour chicken "authentic".  That being said it is amazingly good at non authentic Asian! 

Pros - Great taste, portions are just right.

Cons - They don't take reservations and the wait can be lengthy at times.  Also, I've been there 5 times now over 3 years and the service is ALWAYS slow.  It's tough to get a refill on anything.  

Note- i'm knocking them down a star due to my recent visit.  They had a magician entertaining a table of girls.  Every time the guy did a trick the girls would literally scream and laugh at the top of their lungs.  It was very distracting.  I know it's vegas and I know it's a Casino but it was excessive and clearly many people thought it distracting as well.

Came here for a quick bite.

Awesome egg noodle soup (think it was a red 8 special) compared to other places on the strip. I don't like Asia Noodle inside of Venetian because their broth is too bland. Dumplings in the noodle soup was sooo flavorful and packed with various ingredients.

Hargow was up to par.

Authentic taste. Cannot compare at ALL to Panda Express so I'm not sure why some reviewers were comparing it to Panda. 
Prices are reasonable for Vegas and being inside Wynn

Red 8 is a pretty good americanized chinese food. I love the Oxtail soup along with their mongolian beef and rice.. The ambiance is really nice and the service is wonderful. The dessert menu can use a bit of work but still ok. The price is a bit expensive , i think your paying for the ambiance and the fact that you are dining at the Wynn.. I don't suggest this place for chinese food. I would only go back here if i was invited, but still glad i checked this restaurant off my list.

Why a restaurant of this quality can manage to open this long?? In Wynn some more?? When we walk into the restaurant we have to greet the hostess first instead of her greeting us.

Then it takes forever just to get our drinks. I mean, our appetisers arrived before our drink and she even ordered the wrong appetiser. If you dont want to work there then go home and send someone else.

I ordered a $22 singapore laksa because they said its their specialty. The noodles were so small portion and although the soup taste good, I realised they probably put lots of msg cos I am thirsty for the rest of the evening. My fiancee ordered an eggplant noodle and yet theres not a single eggplant in it, I think she ordered a pork feet for her instead. We are too hungry to care so we just carry on munching  on those little portion of foods.

You spent $70 and u are still hungry, man, should've gone to chinatown. 

Anyway, when they delivered the bill, it was ridiculous, they put some stuff that we didnt even ordered. CHECK UR BILL BEFORE YOU PAID.

Absolutely make sure you CHECK UR BILL!!! I would never come back thats for sure. Red 8 my ass you should call urself one done!!!

Out of all the restaurants in the Wynn this is hands down my favorite restaurant. It is casual and all the dishes are superb. As a starter I love their hot and sour soup like no other! And as the entree I can order the spicy soft shell crab all day.  There is no going wrong with this restaurant. Wish I was in Vegas now this is definitely where I would be for lunch even for dinner!  Sometimes the wait can be annoying especially when you are hungry but its worth the wait in my opinion.

Whenever my extended family stays at the Wynn (more than I'd like to admit...), we always enjoy a meal at Red 8. The Asian food here is really yummy and it's fun to look out the "window" into the Wynn casino.

Last time, I enjoyed one of the most delicious cocktails I'd ever tasted. I ordered fresh watermelon juice with vodka and it was SO good!!! I always fill up on the family-style Asian food too and then head into the Casino to work off the food ;)

Red 8 is accommodating for young children and not as expensive as one would expect of a restaurant in the Wynn.

The service was horrible! We are staying at the Wynn and they promoted this place in an article in our room. The spareribs were small little individual ribs. $25.00 for combination fried rice? There was no seafood in the rice. I am giving it 2 stars cause my husband said his oxtail soup was good. Can I say the service is bad again! They were slow with preparing our dinner. We waited 45 mins on the reservation list, they were supposed to text us, and they didn't we had to come back and ask if our table was ready. Once we sat, we waited over 45 mins four our food.  The portions are also small.  I just do not recommend them.

First thing to know, this is a restaurant in the Wynn - it is going to be expensive.
When it comes to the food, Red 8 is definitely above average. Every dish that I had was enjoyable and slightly different from the mainstream versions. The chicken lettuce cups (basic I know) were light and flavorful. The spicy pork with bell peppers was decent; everything I expected and nothing that I didn't. But the deep fried chicken with chili sauce absolutely made the meal for me. The sour/spicy flavor balanced well with the light/crispy crust of the chicken. Highly recommend this dish. 
Overall the meal was good. Don't come into the meal with the highest of expectations or shallow pockets and you will come out of it happy.
small portion dishes, packed w/ people and super slow service.  food was okay, I liked my Singapore fried rice noodle.  for the price they charge, I say so somewhere else ~

The only place that I stay in Vegas is the Wynn, and the main reason is the awesome food. I am gluten free so it's hard to find good Chinese, but this place is awesome! It's located near the towers where I usually stay, so it's super convenient. Get the cashew chicken!

I'm really surprised at the low rating Red 8 has gotten here.  I think this is an excellent place for Chinese.  I make sure to go each trip.  

I don't find it to be that expensive considering it's really good and in the Wynn.  I would like to see a bigger Dim Sum selection.  But the BBQ pork is top notch.  

I did knock a star off for slow service.  I once walked out (without paying) after waiting 15 minutes for my check.

Well, It is kind of hard to find decent Chinese food on the Strip or even China Town. Somehow, in my opinion, Red 8 had pulled it off. On my most recent visit to Red 8, they had made some improvement to the quality of the food and a noticeable change can be compared to my earlier visits. For example, They no longer cook Xiao Long Bao in small foil. I also tried their pepper and salted seabass and it was heavenly. The crispy pork also taste really good and so was the duck. I recommend any patron who visited this restaurant to order to BBQ combination plate for its varieties of meat. I would definitely come back here again!!!

The interior presentation and overall experience in general were impressive, but for the steep price we paid, the food and service left much to be desired. 

In terms of food, the dishes were good but lacking any flavor to really set them apart from typical Westernized Chinese cuisine. The Mapo Tofu dish in particular could have used more heat and flavor, a flavor that I expected since the dish originates in my mom's hometown but didn't get. I did like the soft, tender texture of the beef dishes we ordered though, and the Malaysian Chicken Satay was excellent. The dim sum dishes we ordered were not anything extraordinary to me; I've definitely had better soup dumplings elsewhere.

Service was very average and a little bit on the slow side. While the overall experience definitely wasn't negative, it was overpriced, and I don't think I'd return considering its value.
Fantastic! Really expansive menu and prices were pretty good for the Wynn. Only complaint was the smoke from the casino was a little much to taste my meal

First impression, this place is beautifully decorated with a lot of red and gold accented furniture. The Asian in me highly approve the decor! 

As for the food, I feel like the entrees are either a hit or miss depending on what you order. I was with a party of 5 and from looking at other dishes I wish I had ordered something different. But instead, my 'Classic dan dan noodles with pork' dish paled in comparison to the Beef Chow Mein or the Mongolian Beef that my friends ordered. My biggest complain about the classic dan dan noodles with pork is that there was no pork and that I had to mix my own sauces and seasoning. The black sauce that came with this dish was super salty so you have to be conservative while mixing it or else you'll end up with a dish that is bland yet overly salty. 

I also asked for the palm pocket, an expensive dim sum item that was nothing to rave about. Now I understand the mix of bad and good ratings for this place. Be careful what you order!

A nice place for causal dine out. Authentic Chinese flavor. Cannot go wrong with any appetizer, dim sum, noodles or soups. Fair price; if you are not looking for a formal place like Wing Lei, Red 8 is where you can get some awesome food. Same taste with the Red 8 at Wynn in Macau. Highly recommend.

I would give it four stars but it was overpriced. I had combo fried rice ($16). The dish was tasty and had two prawns in it but c'mon $16? REALLY? 

I did see a TV star sitting across from me. I'm sure she could afford to eat here more often than I.

I'm a little surprised to see that Red 8 only gets 3 stars I ate their last night and really enjoyed it. The quality of food and service was just fine. I had the Mongolian chicken and Andy had Sweet and Sour Chicken both were large portions and very good. we shared Dim Sum Pork and Shrimp that was really well made. it was a little expensive but what isn't in Vegas.

Stayed at the Wynn for 4 days and came here 4 days in a row. Don't know why my parents like this place so much. Maybe its convenient? I think its way too overpriced. 

Also probably had the worst milk tea here. Boba was hard and the tea was watery.

Restaurant experience was good but not great. First off service was not very good and not with a smile. The front hostess was actually rude to my mother who joined our table later. When we were seated we were placed in what appeared to be an interesting table in a separate area with a view of the casino. There was an open metal lattice wall but unfortunately the smoking lounge was right across the walkway. Smoke wafted into the restaurant and our table the entire time. This may be acceptable in a place where casinos allow smoking but it ruined our experience particularly for an expensive meal.
We had the pork wonton appetizer which was good and spicy but not what I expected. They were pork dumplings and not fried. Menu was not very detailed about the appetizer. Had the orange beef and Kung Poa chicken. Both acceptable normal Chinese dishes with nothing great.
Being in that smaller area made it difficult to identify our hostess who only came to check on us once halfway through the meal. We did not stay for dessert.
Good Americanized Chinese food and service. The fried rice was really flavorful and fluffy. Kinda pricey but that's Vegas for you.

It's all relative.  This four star review is considering that I'm eating at Wynn right by the casino floor.  I've come to learn that almost ALL Vegas restaurants located on premises for all the major resorts are a complete rip off.  That includes getting something as simple as a sandwich.  So if I'm going to pay $20 an entree, I might as well get some decent Chinese food.

The decor is Asian themed and pretty cool.  It's super convenient for those who are gambling or for those like me that are staying at the Wynn and don't want to wander off the resort to grab a meal.

Service was also pretty good for a Vegas restaurant.

Ok let's get to the food.  I ordered Mongolian Beef and Roasted Duck and a bowl of white rice.  They were extremely generous with the amount of beef in the Mongolian beef dish, like there was a lot!  I was impressed.

And their roasted duck was very meaty and crispy.  I was expecting subpar duck but it passed the test.

So overall, it was a pretty good meal.  Let's not talk about value cause there is no value to be had eating on premises of any of the big casinos.  

I left Red8 content and enjoying the people that served me, from the waitstaff to the hostess.

Horrible experience before we saw the Le Reve show....so my mom ordered the braised beef noodle soup...Please watch out for this..the meat was disgusting and some of the meat was black and the other was a big piece of fat..and the smell was rotten....
I ordered the BBQ platter...it was ok but for almost 30 dollars it was a tiny amount...and my daughters orange chicken was hard as well as the white rice it came with(very hard old  rice)..
WAYYYY OVER PRICED!!! No one even came to see how we were doing..no refills,..the bill was close to 100 dollars..we didn't even order alcohol.....don't do it....go get a burger at the cafe or something.....never again....I am a local and was so surprised that the WYNN would even accept such low quality food.....

Probably one of the worst "Asian" food experiences I've had in my entire life. 

For being at such a classy and glamorous location as The Wynn, I expected so much more. The only saving grace of this place is their unique selection of cocktails. Everything that we ordered was overcooked, drenched in oil, and lacked flavor. I do not recommend this place to anyone wanting to have a quality LV experience. Save you $$ and get sushi/Asian at the MGM.

Great food

Good vegan and vegaterian options

Pricey 

Great service 

Spring rolls were amazing. 

Amazing martinis

They get a three for being able to seat a party of 12 right away without reservations. That was great to not have to wait! The food, while not stellar by a Chinese person's standard, passes as decent junkie Chinese food.

Our table ordered several dim sum dishes, fried rice, fried noodles, sweet and sour pork, mongolian beef, and others that I can't recall. Everything was really salty, and when I tried to take sips of my mango juice to wash the saltiness away, my mango juice tasted like medicine and left a bitter aftertaste in my mouth. I have to say though, the flavors were on par with what you'd expect (sweet and sour tasted like it would at another restaurant, the dim sum tastes like it would elsewhere, etc). 

Our waiter was very accommodating, especially since our party kept growing as people came wandering in late. He was very good about making sure we had our drinks, that the newcomers were included and got food, etc.

Overall, good solid service, food is average, but definitely something I'd eat again if in the right company/mood.

I've never really had a bad experience here at Red 8. I've probably eaten here about 10 times. I didn't have any service issues here. The servers pretty much only came out when they were needed, but they were easy to flag down to get what you needed. My only big gripe is that the dim sum selection is a bit smaller than you would expect at a Chinese restaurant. However, the two items that shine for me are the fresh guava juice (Yum! Definitely not Kern's nectar) and the egg custard buns. The pricing is a bit above average, but this is Vegas... and it's the Wynn. Show me a restaurant in a Vegas hotel/casino that isn't priced above your local Chinatown dim sum joint.
went for dim sum last summer after graduation MEDICORE! it was not that good at all

Ok food, good atmosphere.  Went here with a large group and had the fried brown rice, which was ok.  This dish as well as other dishes was not very spicy.  The service was good.  I wish they had slightly better chopsticks though, given the effort put into the rest of their ambiance.
Great food, I really like coming here. The food is so good, it's my favorite place to eat dim sum in Las Vegas

Who loves paying $22 for chow fun? How about $25 for congee? 

Me. Me. Me. 

NOT. 

Come on, seriously? If it tasted amazing, i'd be more than willing to pay that much. But I can get better chow fun just 5 minutes away on Spring Mountain Road or even better, at a ghetto place in Monterey Park! 

Anyways, I came here yesterday for lunch. We ordered: abalone congee, yang chow fried rice, two different vegetables (not sure what the English name is, but that doesn't matter), wonton noodles, and various dim sum dishes. 

The abalone congee was around $25, but the whole time I thought "where is the abalone?" I seriously think they shredded a few pieces of abalone in there to officially charge that much (..obviously). The yang chow fried rice was really delicious, I give them street cred for that one. The wonton noodles were good, but it didn't taste authentic Asian. It tasted quite Americanized, especially the soup base. Fail. As far as the dim sum goes, it was actually quite tasty -- yes, all of it. It was on the more expensive side, around $6-$12 per dim sum dish, which is actually quite expensive for dim sum. 

Our bill for 4 people came out to around $120. Not bad for the Wynn. But if I went to a place in Chinatown, the same food (with the same taste, if not better) would probably have been $40 bucks. Gotta love it.

Minus one star for service.

The Wynn did a great job on decor for this place, it's really red. It has a super authentic feel with all Chinese workers. However, the prices are somewhat high for asian food, but not too high where it was ridiculous. The quality is definitely up their.

Egg rolls- skip it. It was wet and soggy inside.
Orange chicken- Loved this dish. I would come back for it. Make sure you get this.
Beef Chowfun- another solid dish
rice- it's rice, you cannot mess this one up.

The 3 dishes I chose paired beautifully together. 

Yes the prices are higher then normal, you are in the Wynn after all.

Really enjoyed the dim sum and appetizers.
The steam pork buns could have had a little more flavor, but not bad.
The lettuce wraps were amazingly delicious.
Great service, very attentive.  We told them we had La Reve tickets at 9:30 and they made sure to get us in and out in perfect amount of time to get to the show on the other side of casino.

One of our favorite places to dine in Vegas!  Lots of great selections, authentic Far East selections.  We've ordered many different items and everything was excellent.  Great service, wonderful atmosphere.  Highly recommended!

Despite staying at the Wynn several times in the past, I've never gone for dinner at the Red  8. On a lark, we changed our plans to go for Italian and instead came here to see how it was. I will admit, part of the allure was their fake chicken options on the menu!

We didn't make reservations but were able to get a table right away. We ordered two appetizers (Ginger String Beans and Jade Dumplings), and entrees consisted of Dan Dan Noodles and Cashew Chik'n. There was a good amount of food and every bit we had was ~*delicious*~. Our server was quick and polite and was able to answer any questions we had.

I was sad the Hot and Sour soup had a chicken base for the broth, as I would have loved to have a bowl of it. 

Highly recommended if you're craving Chinese food!

The service at this place is super slow to the point of nonexistence, the food comes out luke warm and don't expect a refill of hot water water for your tea, we waited 20 minutes and the server finally came back as we walking out the restaurant with the teapot.  The won ton soup is good but I wished they would have served it hot. The the crab noodles are pretty good but super greasy!
I absolutely love the food here. The atmosphere is warm and inviting.  Can't wait to go back to Vegas to visit again. The dumplings are unlike any I've ever had!

My husband and I came in for late lunch. Waited for about 10 minutes which is no big deal. Our server was very attentive to us. I ordered Tofu in claypot with salted fish and my husband ordered Penang Char Kway Teow. Both food were outstanding.
The price of each food (about $15) is a bit much, but the portion is pretty good and the location is obviously at Wynn Hotel. 
I would definitely comeback whenever I'm in Vegas.

Yummy Chinese!!  The service was decent and the food was great.  We shared a bunch of dishes and were adventurous.  They have good cocktails too.  It is Vegas priced.  We did not have reservations and were able to walk right in.  Great for groups, but they had tables for two as well.  Enjoy!!

Nice to see that Red 8 is still going strong, with ever changing dining options on the strip. 
 Came on Sunday night and was quoted 20 min wait for two, which held true, I killed time watching dancing fountains sputter to the Sinatra B side and Disney tunes outside. 
 I am a big fan of roast duck noodles, the soup version, and though it wasn't on the menu, they happily fulfilled my request without hesitation, even asked if I wanted duck deboned- yes, please! 
 For appetizer we got fried soft shell crab- pure indulgence, deep fried and calorie laden, with jalapeños and roasted garlic, delicious! 
 I also had jasmine tea, which was a very nice flavor, and dessert of lemon grass pannacota. I love pannacota and love lemon grass, and though I never, ever order dessert, I couldn't resist. I thought it was delicious, though could have done without topping of chopped mango and strawberry, that was kind of a sloppy afterthought. 
 Service was spotty, a bit slow and some people around us got impatient. 
 All in all, you can certainly get Chinese food for less than $100 for two (no alcohol), so it's a once in a while indulgence.

This place serves standard chinese food in a slightly more upscale setting.  It's an easy spot to grab a bite to eat while at the Wynn.  Great service and  you will get out of there for about $30 a person.  If you are a people watcher get a table by the window and make fun of all the people you see strolling thru the casino.
When at the Wynn I always get lunch here. If you don't go with high expectations you won't be disappointed.

I love staying at the Wynn.  I had been looking forward to eating here after running out of time on the last 3 stays. I was really underwhelmed. The Wynn has many other better options.

This is some of the least authentic Chinese food I have ever had. 
The Panda Express at a shopping mall food court is more authentic than this.

The Dan Dan noodles was cheap ramen with a squirt of bottled Hosin sauce and Sriracha. This would be like ordering spaghetti marinara and getting ketchup for the tomato sauce. 

The chicken satay was deep fried not grilled. Yuck., How do you think a sirloin steak would taste is you decided to deep fry it instead of putting it on a broiler.

Head over to the Encore side and try the asian restaurant there, it is way better.

Conveniently located within the Wynn. We had the Singaporean Laksa (pretty rare to find in restaurants), green beans with ginger, and noodle soup with cat-ear shaped noodles. Everything was pretty good. Fairly pricey for what it is though, e.g., Laksa was $22, dim sum items were $9 each.

************* REVIEW 121 ****************

Always great service, my parents love it here as well! Food is consistent in taste. Oh, no swimsuit or sheer clothes allowed at this place. My girl friend had to change her clothe the last trip we were here! So dress appropriate please (look who's talking!)

- Famous wonton noodle soup!
- Beef brisket egg nooddle soup.
- Chinese Kale (CAI-LAN) Stir Fried topped with Spring Garlic.
- Shumai & Ha Cao - Chinese dumpling.

Great in taste, as good as Noodle at Bellagio, better than Beijing 9 at the Mandalay Bay & Noodle House in Caesars! 

Final note:

I don't understand why people complain about the price, I mean it's the real estate at these hotels, what do you expect? 

I live in the ghetto neighborhood of the Bay Area & when I pay f$9 for a bowl on wonton soup, now that expensive in my book! $11 in San Francisco, that's fair. $15 for Vegas, it's acceptable! Nuff said?

Got into Vegas and didn't want to leave the hotel for dinner. Didn't want to spend $200 on dinner at the higher end places so we opted for Red 8.
The decor and atmosphere is nice. We ordered a mixed drink and it was nice. Started with the Hot and Sour soup (good but not outstanding) and the Traditional Beijing Noodles with sauce (good). I asked the waiter why the noodles didn't have any pork and he told me it is ground up in the sauce. It would probably good to have that described on the menu.
I opted for the $23 roast duck. The duck and sauce were tasty but that was it...you got a few pieces of duck and sauce...no veggies, no rice no nothing...$23.
My husband ordered the lamb special $28. Cooked nicely and he enjoyed the sauce. At least with his dinner he received rice.
Overall the food was good but still overpriced for what you received. Total for dinner was $100 not including tip.

Good place for lunch. It has all of the usuals albeit with a price tag thats shameless even for Vegas standards. $22 for a side of baby back choy? Is it free range? I'll admit the noodles were good and I would recommend the bbq pork belly. It's also open from lunch all the way to 1am.

I'm not sure why this place only has 3 stars?!?!

This is a must go when I'm at Wynn!!! Always go for lunch but it's overall high quality Chinese food!!!

I've ordered everything from the dim sums, congee, braised abalone, soup noodles, sweet and sour pork, crispy noodles, house fried rice... And many more!!!

My favs are the abalone congee, crispy fried noodles, fried rice, pot stickers, shiu Mai, sweet and sour pork and their noodle soup. Pretty much everything I've tried is great! Also the chicken items are always soooo tender. 

Service is great ( most of the time) the hosts are always very nice!!

Better than wing lei. DO NOT go there!!!

Unfriendly host.  Doesn't even speak Chinese.  Tells us to park stroller on the ramp and then disappears.  There are 2 ramps.  Could have at least clarified it.  I sense they don't like to serve Chinese people.  This is weird.  We are probably the first to come here.

I was most definitely underwhelmed by this place. My aunt hyped it up a bit. She kept talking about the preserved egg congee, so it got us a little excited.

Damn, damn. Just looking at the menu made me not want to eat. Padt thai for 23 bucks? No thanks. I didn't want the congee because it wouldn't make me full, so I got the udon with fish balls and fish cakes. That was only 12 bucks but soo underwhelming. There was no flavor at all so I had to add a whole bunch of chili oil. My aunts liked it but my dish was definitely not good. I tried some of my cousins padt thai. I could have gotten the same in San Jose for half the price. Not coming back.. well maybe I'll try the congee one day.
I never come to Vegas without eating here. Its usually a long wait since they don't take reservations but always worth it. LOVE
The dining experience was bad.  The service was terrible. They did not follow any of our requests and had to send back the food!

Very overpriced and blandly mediocre.  Service is sloooowww- you will literally go for 15 minute stretches without seeing a single waiter or busboy.  My soup noodles smelled disconcertedly like hot urine.  "Chicken" lettuce wraps are 90% minced water chestnuts.  Add a 25 minute wait just to be seated, and it's just salt in the wound.

If you're looking for tastier Chinese food, bite the bullet and walk to the Venetian, where Noodle Asia serves up far superior hangover recovery food.

I was very much looking forward to dining at Red 8. And yes, the food was okay. And yes, the restaurant decor is slick and cool, giving it a very hip atmosphere.

But I'm sorry, the menu is not that imaginitive or extensive, and frankly I've had food of this par from Chinese takeout. Also, the service was only so-so. 

In other words, it's WAY over priced for what you get. Seriously, don't bother.

I had lunch here today and it was nothing special. I had their dim sum and I think the the taste was just mediocre.  The quality of the food was alright as it didn't taste bad, but was not super tasty as well. 

I only waited for about for about 5 minutes for my table. The food came about relatively quick, but I didn't see the waiter come by again until I finished my meal.

Wynn and Encore Casino do next to nothing wrong. The attention to detail in just about everything they do is equal to or better than anything you will find on the strip. Sadly, Red 8 is the single exception. Had a meal here, and was terribly disappointed. Bland, no flavor, nothing interesting about it at all. And being in Las Vegas, of course it was very expensive. Would never go back or advise a good friend to visit. I might suggest my worst enemy enjoy a meal here however.

Red 8 is Wynn's informal Asian restaurant, open for lunch and dinner.  It serves a variety of Southeast Asian foods: Malaysian satays, Japanese noodles, Cantonese noodles and, on weekends, Hong Kong style dim sum.

Wynn Las Vegas has an array of excellent restaurants - all of them expensive.  Red 8 tries to fill a niche by providing good food at a modest price, relatively speaking.  Many dishes are in the $15 - $20 range, although there are a few luxury live seafood items that will set you back almost $100.

The breadth of the menu is surprising.  Among its offerings are Malaysian beef satays, Korean kim chee, Japanese udon noodles, Vietnamese pho, pad Thai, Indian mee goreng noodles, and Cantonese roast duck.  There's a single menu for lunch and dinner.

The restaurant is decorated in black, white and cream, with red accents.  Considering its location next to the casino, it's fairly quiet, with an informal feel.  There's a small communal table, but it doesn't seem very, well...communal.  I haven't noticed any conversations between strangers, and management doesn't help when it treats the table as overflow space when no other tables are available.

Service is a weak link at Red 8.  On my first visit, after I was finished eating, my server disappeared.  I waited for 15 minutes (actually a little bit longer than that, as I didn't check my watch right away), looking around for someone.  I finally managed to flag down a bus boy, and asked him to get my server.  She appeared a couple of minutes later, with no explanation.  On my second visit, service was better, but again there were some long waits.  On my third visit, I imitated a gentleman at a neighboring table who took a more direct approach: loudly hailing the server like a passing taxicab.  Crude, but effective.


** DIM SUM
Dim Sum is available for lunch on weekends.  There are no rolling carts; ordering is from a menu.  Each order comes as two or three pieces, so it would be more fun to order as a group, but ordering solo worked out OK.  It took a little while to prepare the food, but the wait wasn't too long.  I had:
*   Shrimp in bean curd rolls.  Like a flat, fried egg roll, it was filled with shrimp, what tasted like shrimp paste, and bits of carrot and some green vegetable.  A dipping bowl contained Worcestershire sauce.  If you like bean curd skin, it's a very tasty dish.
*   Deep fried taro dumplings.  Light and crispy outside, with soft (mashed?) taro inside, mixed with barbecue pork.  Very good+.
*   Sticky rice in lotus leaf.  A rectangle of soft, sticky rice, with small shrimp and barbecued pork, wrapped in a lotus leaf.
*   Thai ice tea.  Layered cream (?) on top of very sweet strong tea.  I liked it, but some people might have been turned off by the sweetness.


** REGULAR MEAL #1
This time, I decided to try something different:
*   Oriental green onion pancake.  Vaguely reminiscent of a quesadilla with scallions, but crispier.  Hoisin sauce was served as a condiment.  It didn't have much flavor; the hoisin sauce helped a little, but not much.
*   Indian mee goreng with shrimp.  Wok-fried noodles, with onion and shrimp, and bits of a very hot pepper.  The portion was very large, probably best shared.  I thought the flavor was good, and the noodles were firm, but it was mostly just a big plate of noodles.


** REGULAR MEAL #2
OK, maybe this doesn't exactly qualify as a regular meal.  However, I noticed a couple of interesting items on the menu, and was hooked.  What seemed so interesting?  Congee.  A thin rice porridge, it's felt to be a healthy dish, appropriate after one has been eating or drinking too well for a few days.  Kind of like thin oatmeal.  However, meat, chicken, fish, and other ingredients may be added to congee.  I chose to add pork and preserved egg.  The egg, sometimes called century egg or thousand year egg, is preserved in an alkaline solution.  Wikipedia has a good explanation. 

The verdict?  Not bad.  As expected, it was pretty bland, but it actually had a little texture.  The pork gave it some flavor, and the preserved egg was interesting.  I don't know if I'd order it again, but I'm glad I tried it once.

I had planned to try an unusual dessert - sweet potato porridge with sago - but the huge bowl of congee had filled me up.  Maybe next time.



Red 8 isn't bad, but it also isn't that good.  Perhaps its menu is too ambitious ("Jack of all trades, master of none").  Perhaps I've been spoiled by all the excellent restaurants at Wynn.  In any case, I was hoping for better.  Nonetheless, it's convenient and not too expensive - and I don't know if there's any place better in this mid-range category.

If you are staying at the Wynn and are starving for some Asian dishes, Red 8 is a great place to tame those cravings. Prices are actually double compared to regular Asian restaurants. However, you are paying for the convenience, location on the Strip (Wynn), and ambiance.

We had the Salt and Pepper Calamari, Stir-Fried Mixed with Chinese Vegetables, and Egg Noodles with Beef mixed with Soy Sauce. I really enjoyed the fact that all these dishes were reminiscent of authentic dishes that I would normally find at a regular Chinese restaurant. The service and cuisine at Red 8 was excellent. I would recommend coming here for a casual Asian lunch or dinner if you are staying at the Wynn.

Had lunch here while staying at the Wynn. They have a wonderful dim sum menu. We had pan fried pork dumplings, chicken and pork lettuce wraps, shrimp and chicken shu mai, BBQ pork buns, vegetable spring rolls. Everything was absolutely delicious. 

They have a whole section of Hong Kong barbecue as well as some Thai and Vietnamese dishes.

Not a typical "American" Chinese food menu so don't expect a lot of those typical combination type dishes here - excellent.

Had the sweet and sour pork with the Red8 special fried rice. The fried rice was excellent. Not loaded with soundalike and garlic, it had a nice fresh flavor - a lot like the food stalls I ate at in Singapore as a child. The sweet and sour pork was a little over cooked and the service a bit slow considering that they were less than half full on a Friday night.

It was another dinner visit to Red 8, this time with another couple in tow, resulting in a reprised 4-1/2-star dining experience!

This time a bowl of classic Hot & Sour Soup was suitably spicy but not overbearing;  Shrimp & Pork Dumpling Noodle Soup was quite nice, as was a lightly sweet Almond Shrimp Dumpling that was covered with almond shavings formed into the shape of small shields.  

Honey Prawns featuring honey glazed walnuts and large shrimps were just sweet enough, while lengths of Beef Tenderloin with Black Pepper Sauce and Black Mushroom added were hot and tender bathed in a nice peppery sauce.  

A scoop of Strawberry Sorbet diminished some of the flames, and provided a refreshing palate cleanser as a fine finish to my meal.

Service was excellent, and the Asian ambiance elegant and sumptuous, yet casual in attitude and tone.

Having had Dim Sum in China Town in LA, NY,  and San Francisco, this was about as close as it comes in Vegas. Everything was tasty and more importantly fresh. Highly recommend. A star off because of the price, but then again it's Wynn.

Ok, granted we were here when Wynn first opened, this place sucked! the service was extremely terrible. the food was mediocre! Gosh....we were not happy at all! This place probably got better but, first impression, "hell no!"

You cannot go wrong with anything that's inside the Wynn resorts, Red 8 is no exception! Right in the middle of the casino, Red 8 has great Chinese food and an open view to the casino floor! 

I ordered the maple BBQ Pork with miso soup and just snacked as I calculated all the fun I was going to get into during my stay.

Come by and enjoy the great food, luxurious scene and even catch a couple famous people running around looking lost, check it out!

Freaking good Chinese food. Went with a group of 6 total and they accommodated us in a neat little nook where we had privacy but a great view. We had crab Rangoon (bomb!), honey glazed walnut shrimp, Malaysian fried rice with chicken and shrimp, pad Thai with shrimp, orange beef (delicious), and deep fried chicken with chili, steamed vegetable medley. Everything was delicious. We had to wait 45 minutes to eat at 10pm but it was definitely worth the wait.

I see why most guests post a 3-star review;
Very simple: great decor, fun food, bad service and no bar. 

We hope for improvement in this amazing hotel. 

Thanks in advace, Manager.

Don't know what all the other bad reviews are about. I'm straight up from Asia and this place actually offers (relatively) authentic Asian food. Penang noodles are on point, as well as the dim sum and vegetable entrees.

Service - A, Ambiance - A, Food - A.
Awesome hangover food :)

We were at the Wynn and decided to have lunch. After checking Yelp, Red 8 looked like it would be a good choice. We were immediately greeted and seated. It was a Saturday and was very busy for the lunch hour. 

They have a nice dim sum menu along with several entrees. We started with the bbq pork buns and steamed shiu mai. Both came out quickly and were hot. The pork buns were okay, but I have had much better. The shiu mai were good, but didn't seem made fresh in house. 

We also ordered the Shanghainese soup dumplings (3). We felt the same about these, they were good but we have definitely had better. We finished with chicken and broccoli which they made special for us and fried rice. The chicken and broccoli came out luke warm but the fried rice was excellent. For a $100 lunch I would expect much better food. 

I saw many reviews complaining about the service but we had excellent service from Joanna and Dorothy throughout the meal. They were very friendly and constantly checked on us and made sure our drinks were full. 

3.5 stars for the food
5 stars for service

Our party of 7 dined here on one of the nights in Vegas because we were at the Wynn and wanted Asian food.

Red 8 is a casual Asian fusion restaurant. You will find Vietnamese, Cantonese, Thai, and Indian here. We ordered a number of dishes and did family style. 

Here's what we ordered: 

Beef Chow Fun
Wonton Soup (2 orders)
Shrimp Walnut
Kung Pao Shrimp
Mongolian Beef

We didn't have high expectations or anything, BUT all the dishes were terrible. It was bland and had no flavor. On top of that, each dish was tiny portions and double the price of the average Chinese restaurant. Service was not great either. I wish he was more attentive. 

Our bill was $150--no drinks with gratuity included. NEVER again.

Even though we eat at Wynn/Encore weekly  (Vegas locals), this is our first visit to Red 8.  

First of all, the food is fantastic.  Probably the best Sweet n Sour I've ever eaten .  Honey Glazed Prawns were massive and tasty!  Also had the combo fried rice and Cashew Chicken.  Definitely a do again.  We realized too late that we had not ordered anything spicy...will do that next time.  

Service was way fast...almost too fast.  Literally like 3 minutes after ordering all the food arrived.  I was hungry but that's a bit quick.  Didnt get to fully enjoy the Ginger Green Bean appetizer. 

Frankly the downer of the place are the seats.  They are child size patio chairs and neither my hubby or I were comfortable.  Our waiter quickly moved us to a bench seat but we saw other diners equally as uncomfortable.  We aren't skinny minis but we aren't huge either.  Kind-of average.  I imagine this is a problem for many people.

Took longer to get the check than the food.  :-(

Service- always not too busy here. We ate around 8-ish at night. The food and drinks came really fast!

Food- spicy beef chow fun looking dish- this was really delicious!
crispy yellow noodle with veggies and chicken- this one was less flavorful, but the crispy noodle was yummy

Drinks- we got 1 drink each weren't too alcohol-ish

Bill was about $80-ish

I want to give them a five star review but since I'm from LA where food is cheap and huge portioned I had to take off a star. I liked, not loved, their braised beef food soup (cause I've had better) but I do think it does wonders to satisfy a late night craving. Their beef tendon melts in your mouth but the portion is way too tiny. At most, it looks like an appetizer to me. It's located in Wynn so it's very easy to locate. I also forgot to mention that their soup is very flavorful. I liked the sour pickled vegetables that they added in.

Not great for vegetarian vegan options. My waiter was very uninterested in helping me navigate the menu. The only vegetarian option he could suggest was the chow mein which was very oily. I complain because they do profess to have options for vegetarians/vegans but other than the sides and the chow mein its pretty dismal.

I wanted to love this place, but it's rather overpriced. The service was the worst part of the meal, as the server halfheartedly took our order and showed no enthusiasm for any recommendations. The food was good, but not amazing. I am sorry to say I won't ever be back :(

I love the Wynn and ate at the buffet today which was very good, but had to comment on Red 8 which I ate at yesterday with my family. 
Our meal for four of us included soup, calamari, a steak dish and dim sum had to be the worst Chinese meal I have eaten in the last few years. 
Chinese food is one of my favorites but I never plan to eat here again.
Great dining experience at the Wynn hotel. This restaurant was private and service was superb, the cherry on top was the showstoppers drink! Try it you will not regret it.

Been here many times and always enjoy their sliced beef with egg congee, shrimp and ground pork wontons and crispy roasted pork belly. I would say the food is pretty authentic but the price is kinda steep.
